choices.text: Chordee correction, meatal advancement, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty
Meatal advancement, chordee correction, glanuloplasty, urethral mobilization

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for correction of hypospadias surgery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chordee correction, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty

 

  • Proximal hypospadias with chordee needs surgical correction and may involve a two-stage repair. The first stage corrects the penile curvature and the second stage repairs the urethra. Circumcision should be avoided as preputial skin may be required for future repairs or revisions. Surgery for hypospadias is best performed by experts in hypospadias surgery and is typically undertaken before the age of 18 months
  • Chordee correction involves straightening the penis, which may have a downward curvature.
  • Urethral mobilization involves the dissection of the urethra from the corpora cavernosa and mobilizing it to a normal anatomical position.
  • Glanuloplasty involves the reconstruction of the glans penis to provide a cosmetically pleasing appearance and improve function.
  • Meatal advancement involves the creation of a normal urethral meatus at the tip of the penis.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed for Cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. What would be the diagnosis according to the given image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gallbladder polyp

 

Given image shows a Gall bladder specimen revealing numerous polyps.

 

Gall Bladder Polyp

 

Majority are either adenomyomatosis or cholesterol polyps and have no malignant potential.

True adenomatous polyp occurs in 0.3–0.5% of the population. The risk of malignant transformation increases with increasing size of the polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholesterosis and Option D. Strawberry Gall bladder: The interior of the gallbladder looks something like a strawberry. The yellow specks (submucous aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters) correspond to the seeds of a strawberry.

 

 

Option C. Gall bladder Carcinoma: Gall bladder Carcinoma specimen resemble chronic cholecystitis on gross examination, often with a thickened wall and possibly a mass. However, the image provided does not show the characteristics typically associated with carcinoma, such as a mass or irregular thickening.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gallbladder polyps, as seen in the image, are common and typically benign, with the risk of malignancy increasing with polyp size. Accurate identification is crucial for appropriate management.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 79, 1709

questions.text:
A woman presents to a clinic with her son, Ram, who has developed symptoms consistent with Measles, including fever and rash. She mentions that Ram's brother, Shyam, exhibited similar symptoms a few days earlier. Which of the following statements regarding the situation are accurate? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Ram is the index case
  2. Shyam is primary case
  3. Ram got infected from Shyam
  4. If mother had reported when Shyam got infection, Ram could have been vaccinated
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are correct

 

Index case: The first case that comes to the notice of the investigator. In this situation, Ram is the index case as he is the one presented to the clinic first.

 

Primary case: The first case of a disease in a population. Shyam, who exhibited symptoms a few days earlier, is the primary case.

 

 Transmission: Given the incubation period of measles (7 to 18 days), it is likely that Ram got infected from Shyam, who was in an infectious state.

 

Post-exposure prophylaxis: If the mother had reported Shyam's infection, Ram could have received post-exposure prophylaxis. This can be in the form of a measles vaccine within 72 hours of exposure or immunoglobulin up to 6 days post-exposure.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Index case → First case that comes to the notice of investigator.
  • Primary case → First case of a disease in a population.
  • Incubation period of measles infection is 7 to 18 days
  • Vaccine can be given within 72 hours of post-exposure and immunoglobulin can be given up to 6 days’ post-exposure.

questions.text: The following procedure is performed for the management of: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Distal cholangiocarcinoma

 

The image shown is of Whipple’s procedure, which can be done for distal cholangiocarcinoma.

 

  • Whipple's procedure, also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy, is a complex surgical procedure that involves removing the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the common bile duct, the gallbladder, and sometimes a portion of the stomach.
  • This procedure is typically performed to treat cancer of the pancreas, duodenum, or the ampulla of Vater

 

Distal cholangiocarcinoma is cancer that occurs in the bile ducts, typically in the lower part of the bile duct near the pancreas. The procedure referred to in the question is often associated with the surgical management of distal cholangiocarcinoma. It involves a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy), which is a complex surgical procedure to remove the affected part of the bile duct, pancreas, and small intestine, and then reconstruct the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Advanced gastric carcinoma: The management of advanced gastric carcinoma typically involves various approaches, including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Surgical procedures such as gastrectomy or lymphadenectomy may be performed depending on the stage and location of the tumor.

 

Option B. Gallbladder carcinoma: Gallbladder carcinoma may be treated with surgical resection, often involving cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) and potentially more extensive procedures if the cancer has spread. However, the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to gallbladder carcinoma.

 

Option D. Chronic calcific pancreatitis: Chronic calcific pancreatitis may require surgical intervention in certain cases, but the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to this condition. Surgical options for chronic pancreatitis may include drainage procedures or resection of the affected pancreatic tissue.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The procedure mentioned in the question, which is often performed to manage distal cholangiocarcinoma, is a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy).

choices.text: Presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies
Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies
Presence of Anti-HBc IgG antibodies

questions.text: Serologic findings of a patient with hepatitis are given below. HBsAg positive, Anti-HBc (total) positive, Anti-HDV (total) positive. Which of the following is most useful in diagnosing HDV co-infection over superinfection? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies

 

To differentiate between HDV co-infection and superinfection, it is essential to understand the nature of these infections:

 

  • Co-infection occurs when a patient acquires both acute HBV and acute HDV simultaneously. The presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies indicates a recent acute HBV infection, which is characteristic of co-infection.
  • Superinfection occurs when a patient with chronic HBV infection acquires an acute HDV infection. In this scenario, the patient has markers of chronic HBV (like Anti-HBc IgG antibodies) along with markers of acute HDV infection.

 

The Anti-HBc IgM antibodies are indicative of an acute HBV infection and are useful for diagnosing co-infection because they show that the HBV infection is recent, which aligns with the scenario of both HBV and HDV being acquired simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High HDV viral load: This can be present in both co-infection and superinfection and does not specifically differentiate between the two.

 

Option C. Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies: These antibodies can be present in both co-infection and superinfection as they indicate an acute HDV infection. Therefore, they are not useful in differentiating between the two conditions.

 

Option D. Presence of Anti-HBc IgG antibodies: This indicates a past or chronic HBV infection. The presence of Anti-HBc IgG is more consistent with superinfection rather than co-infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies is most useful in diagnosing HDV co-infection over superinfection because it indicates a recent acute HBV infection, which is characteristic of co-infection.

choices.text: 1 month
3 months
No need to stop
Can be stopped and conceived soon after stopping

questions.text: A lady who had undergone mastectomy for breast cancer is being treated with tamoxifen. How long should it be stopped for before she can conceive?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 months

 

  • Tamoxifen is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM), which is used in Premenopausal women having ER +ve breast cancer, because of its anti-estrogenic action in the breast. It prevents the chance of recurrence of breast cancer after surgery.
  • The half-life of tamoxifen is approximately 5 to 7 days, but its active metabolites can persist in the body for several weeks. To minimize any risk to a potential pregnancy, it is recommended to stop tamoxifen at least 3 months before trying to conceive.
  • Tamoxifen has teratogenic effects, such as craniofacial abnormalities and reproductive tract abnormalities. It is also stopped during lactation as it is secreted in breast milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen should be stopped for at least 3 months before attempting to conceive due to its long half-life and potential teratogenic effects. This ensures that the drug and its active metabolites are sufficiently cleared from the body, reducing the risk of harm to the fetus.

questions.text: What is the ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3:1

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in the blood of a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Lymphocytes in human circulating blood are approximately 80 to 90 percent T cells, and 10 to 20 percent B cells. The T-cell to B-cell ratio in the normal marrow varies between 4:1 and 5:1, and a significant increase in T-cell numbers was observed in reactive and myelodysplastic states.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Ratio of CD4 to CD8 T-cells is 2:1.

choices.text: Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy

questions.text: In a case of blunt abdominal trauma, a 30-year-old male patient presents with pelvic fracture, minimal urine output on catheterization, and no blood at the meatus. The radiological image shows extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity. What is the preferred next step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparotomy

 

The pattern of contrast extravasation in the given image suggests intraperitoneal bladder rupture, which is caused by a blow or fall on the distended bladder. The preferred next step of management, in this case, is laparotomy for repair and bladder drainage (suprapubic and urethral catheter). Hence, the correct option is C) Laparotomy. Laparoscopic approaches are also now being used.

 

Laparotomy is the preferred next step in management when a patient presents with of extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity (intra-peritoneal rupture), as it may lead to chemical peritonitis. This suggests a significant bladder injury, and a laparotomy is necessary to assess the extent of the injury and provide appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy may be considered in cases of pelvic fracture and suspected urethral rupture. Absence of blood at urethral meatus rules out urethral rupture.

 

Option B. Perurethral catheterization: Perurethral catheterization may not be the best choice in this situation. It is preferred in extra-peritoneal ruptures.

 

Option D. Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy: Pelvic packing and percutaneous nephrostomy may be considered in certain cases of pelvic trauma but are not the primary management options when there is evidence of intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium leprae

 

Based on the ocular manifestations of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae is the most likely causative organism.

 

  • Ocular symptoms include:
    • Lagophthalmos (inability to close the eyelids) due to the involvement of the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve. Other causes of lagophthalmos include extreme proptosis (bulging of the eyes) and symblepharon (adhesion of the eyelids to the eyeball).
    • Corneal anesthesia is due to the involvement of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve, which innervates the cornea.
    • Corneal ulceration
    • Episcleritis
    • Iris atrophy
  • In addition, patients may present with:
    • Cataract,
    • Glaucoma,
    • Madarosis (loss of eyelashes or eyebrows)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A:

 

  • Acanthamoeba castellanii can cause acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • Symptoms include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and foreign body sensation.
  • Results from direct corneal contact with infected material.
  • Contact lens users are at an increased risk.
  • Radial keratoneuritis is pathognomonic.

 

Option C:

 

  • Onchocerca volvulus causes onchocerciasis, commonly seen in African countries.
  • Symptoms include sclerosing keratitis, uveitis, chorioretinitis, and optic neuritis.
  • Ultimately, it can lead to optic atrophy.

 

Option D:

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis serovars A, B, Ba, and C are responsible for hyperendemic (blinding) trachoma.
  • The source of infection is infected conjunctival discharge.
  • If there is no secondary bacterial infection, symptoms include lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge, and foreign body sensation.
  • Conjunctival congestion and follicles, papillary hyperplasia, Herbert follicles (seen in the limbal area), and progressive pannus are the characteristic features.
  • Serovars D to K cause neonatal and adult inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • Neonates present with conjunctival discharge, chemosis, and swollen lids.
  • Adult inclusion conjunctivitis is more commonly seen in sexually active adults and presents with foreign body sensation, mild photophobia, and mucopurulent discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation—are indicative of neurogenic involvement, which is characteristic of leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presented with withdrawal symptoms. His liver function tests showed:

 

AST 140 IU/L,

 

ALT 110 IU/L, and

 

GGT 500 IU/L.

 

Which of the following benzodiazepines can be safely administered to this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lorazepam

 

The patient's liver function tests indicate elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT, and GGT), suggesting potential alcoholic hepatitis or liver impairment. In such cases, choosing the appropriate benzodiazepine is crucial due to the liver's role in drug metabolism.

 

Lorazepam is a preferred benzodiazepine in patients with liver impairment for the following reasons:

 

  1. Short-acting: Lorazepam is a short-acting benzodiazepine, which means it has a shorter half-life and less risk of accumulation in the body compared to long-acting benzodiazepines.
  2. Minimal liver metabolism: Lorazepam undergoes minimal hepatic metabolism, which makes it safer for patients with impaired liver function. This reduces the risk of adverse effects and toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diazepam: Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine. It undergoes extensive hepatic metabolism, leading to active metabolites that can accumulate, especially in patients with liver dysfunction. This increases the risk of prolonged sedation and toxicity.

 

Option B. Alprazolam: Alprazolam, although shorter-acting than diazepam, still undergoes significant liver metabolism. It is not as safe as lorazepam in patients with compromised liver function.

 

Option C. Clonazepam: Clonazepam is also a long-acting benzodiazepine with extensive hepatic metabolism. Like diazepam, its use in patients with liver impairment can lead to accumulation and increased risk of side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with liver impairment, such as those with alcoholic hepatitis, lorazepam is the preferred benzodiazepine due to its short-acting nature and minimal hepatic metabolism.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 -1 - 3 - 4- 5

 

The auditory pathway begins at the peripheral sensory receptors and progresses through a series of nuclei and tracts in the central nervous system before reaching the auditory cortex. The correct sequence from the periphery to the higher centers is:

 

  • Spiral ganglion (2): Located in Rosenthal's canal within the cochlea, the spiral ganglion contains bipolar neurons that send fibers through the cochlear nerve (part of the eighth cranial nerve) to the brainstem.
  • Cochlear nucleus (1): The first central auditory nucleus where the cochlear nerve fibers terminate.
  • Superior olivary nucleus (3): Serves as a major binaural processing center in the brainstem, crucial for localizing sounds in space.
  • Inferior colliculus (4): Acts as an important relay station in the midbrain, integrating auditory input before sending it to the thalamus.
  • Medial geniculate body (5): Part of the thalamus, this structure further processes auditory information before transmitting it to the auditory cortex.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA).

  1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve

  2. Cochlear Nucleus

  3. Superior Olivary nucleus

  4. Lateral lemniscus

  5. Inferior colliculus

  6. Medial geniculate body

  7. Auditory cortex

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 15

questions.text: NAPQI is the metabolite of which of the following drug toxicity? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Paracetamol


N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) is a metabolite of paracetamol drug toxicity.

 

NAPQI is highly reactive and has high affinity for sulfydryl groups. It causes enzymatic dysfunction in the liver. Normally, minor amounts of NAPQI produced in our body are rapidly eliminated by conjugation with reduced glutathione (GSH) that acts as a source of sulfhydryl group and then excreted into the urine.

 

Therefore, paracetamol toxicity is treated with N-acetyl cysteine (NAC), which provides the sulfhydryl group. NAC thereby helps in the excretion of NAPQI from the body.

 

The maximum recommended dose of acetaminophen is 4g/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin toxicity is not associated with NAPQI. Aspirin overdose primarily causes metabolic acidosis, respiratory alkalosis, and can lead to salicylate poisoning.

 

Option C. Diclofenac: Diclofenac toxicity does not involve NAPQI. Diclofenac is an NSAID that can cause gastrointestinal and renal toxicity.

 

Option D. Ketorolac: Ketorolac toxicity is not associated with NAPQI. Like other NSAIDs, ketorolac can cause gastrointestinal bleeding and renal toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NAPQI is a toxic metabolite produced during the metabolism of paracetamol. In cases of paracetamol overdose, NAPQI accumulates and causes liver damage. The antidote for paracetamol toxicity is N-acetylcysteine (NAC), which helps detoxify NAPQI by replenishing glutathione and providing sulfhydryl groups.

choices.text: Sensory level is from T10 to L1
Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8
In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1
In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding innervation of the uterus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8

 

Explanation:

 

The incorrect statement regarding the innervation of the uterus is option B. Uterine contractility is primarily mediated by hormonal mechanisms rather than by specific spinal innervations. Hormones such as estrogen, prostaglandins, and oxytocin play a significant role in inducing uterine contractions, while progesterone helps maintain uterine relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensory level is from T10 to L1: The sensory innervation of the uterus is indeed from spinal levels T10 to L1. These afferent fibers enter the spinal cord via the inferior hypogastric plexus and are responsible for transmitting sensory information from the uterus.

 

Option C. In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1: During the 1st stage of labor, pain is mediated by spinal segments T10 to L1. This pain is due to the distension of the cervix and lower uterine segment, as well as the contraction of the uterus.

 

Option D. In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction: In early labor, pain is usually related to uterine contractions, which stimulate nociceptors in the genital tract and can cause discomfort and pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterine contractility is not mediated by innervations from spinal level T7 - T8; instead, it is primarily influenced by hormonal mechanisms.

 

 

Ref: Page 500, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: A is Na+, B is K+
A is Na+, B is Ca2+
A is K+, B is Ca2+
A is Ca2+, B is K+

questions.text: A and B in the graph below represent which of the following ions, in terms of permeability for action potential generation: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A is Na+, B is K+

 

Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

 

In the given graph, showing action potential generation in terms of ion permeability, wave A represents Na+ and B represents K+

 

The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in 7 steps as described below.

 

  1. Resting-state - Both channels are closed
  2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.
  3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs
  4. Sodium conductance decreases.
  5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.
  6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.
  7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an action potential, the initial rapid depolarization is due to an increase in Na+ permeability (represented by A), followed by repolarization due to an increase in K+ permeability (represented by B).

questions.text: During the assessment of the breathing component of a trauma patient, which of the following is the most life-threatening injury that should be identified and managed immediately? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tension pneumothorax

 

Injuries that significantly impair ventilation in the short term, such as tension pneumothorax, must be identified during the primary survey and treated immediately.

 

It is important to note that the ABCDE protocol of trauma care should be followed, with the primary survey focusing on identifying and managing life-threatening injuries, followed by the secondary survey to identify all other injuries

 

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, causing it to collapse. This can lead to a rapid buildup of pressure in the chest cavity, compressing the heart and great vessels, which can be life-threatening. It is crucial to identify and manage tension pneumothorax promptly by performing a needle decompression to release the trapped air.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical spine injury: While cervical spine injuries can be serious and require prompt attention, they are not primarily related to the respiratory system. They can result in neurological deficits but are not immediately life-threatening in terms of breathing.

 

Option C. Blunt cardiac injury: Blunt cardiac injury can result from chest trauma and may affect the heart's function. While it can be serious, it may not immediately impact the patient's ability to breathe. However, it requires evaluation and management.

 

Option D. Flail chest: Flail chest is no longer considered an immediate threat to life as per ATLS 2018 guidelines.

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) West syndrome

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

 

  • West syndrome is a severe generalised epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:
    • Infantile spasm
    • Developmental regression
    • Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes.

 

Treatment of West syndrome includes:

 

  • ACTH
  • Vigabatrin when associated with tuberous sclerosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: Young adults who have juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) commonly experience myoclonic jerks in the morning. Valproate is helpful in treating benign myoclonic epilepsy, whereas levetiracetam is helpful in treating severe myoclonic epilepsies.

 

Option B. Rolandic epilepsy: Rolandic epilepsy is benign epilepsy seen in children. They present at night or while awakening.

 

Option D. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS): Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a rare but severe form of childhood epilepsy characterized by a triad of multiple seizure types, characteristic EEG findings, and intellectual impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with painless, massive lower gastrointestinal bleeding. He is diagnosed with Meckel's diverticulum, and surgical treatment is planned. Which of the following is the most commonly encountered ectopic tissue in Meckel's diverticulum? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastric and pancreatic

 

Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital anomaly caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct during gestation. The rule of 2s mnemonic for Meckel's diverticulum includes 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric and pancreatic), located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve, approximately 2 inches in length, and with a 2% incidence.

 

Meckel's diverticulum can present with painless, massive lower gastrointestinal bleeding, and it can be a lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception. Diagnosis is confirmed with a 99mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect gastric mucosa and pancreatic tissue.

 

Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel's diverticulum, and V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is commonly performed.

choices.text: Albendazole is the drug of choice
Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans
Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the given image is correct? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans

 

The given image shows hymenolepis nana egg. Egg is spherical or ovoid and has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar. Filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

Hymenolepis nana is the smallest and the most common tapeworm found in the human intestine.

 

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children. There are usually no symptoms but in heavy infections, there is nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may occur due to an allergic response.

 

Praziquantel (single dose of 25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice, since it acts both against the adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide 500 mg BD for 3 days may be used as alternative.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Albendazole is the drug of choice: This is incorrect. The drug of choice for Hymenolepis nana is praziquantel (a single dose of 25 mg/kg) because it acts against both adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide (500 mg BD for 3 days) may be used as an alternative.

 

Option C. Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants: This is incorrect. The infection with Hymenolepis nana is not acquired through aquatic plants. Infections are usually acquired by ingestion of contaminated food or water or by autoinfection.

 

Option D. Non-segmented leaf-like parasite: This is incorrect. Hymenolepis nana is a segmented tapeworm, not a non-segmented leaf-like parasite.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the most common and smallest tapeworm in humans. Majority of infections are asymptomatic. The drug of choice is praziquantel.

 

Parasites with aquatic plants as the source of infection:

 

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Watsonius watsoni
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis

choices.text: Echocardiography for cardiac disease
Urine analysis for bacteriuria
Blood sugar levels for GDM
VDRL for syphilis

questions.text: The following cost-effective investigations are routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echocardiography for cardiac disease

 

Explanation:

 

Echocardiography for cardiac disease is not part of routine antenatal screening. While it is important for detecting cardiac conditions, echocardiography is typically performed only if there is a known or suspected cardiac disease. Routine screening for all antenatal mothers does not include echocardiography due to its cost and the specific indications required for its use.

 

Routine antenatal screening is designed to identify common conditions that may affect the health of the mother and baby.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Urine analysis for bacteriuriaUrine analysis for bacteriuria: This test is routinely performed to detect asymptomatic bacteriuria, which, if left untreated, can lead to urinary tract infections and increase the risk of preterm labor.

 

Option C. Blood sugar levels for GDM Blood sugar levels for GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus): Screening for GDM is essential to identify women who develop diabetes during pregnancy, which can affect both maternal and fetal health.

 

Option D. VDRL for syphilis: The VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) test is a screening tool for syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection that can have serious consequences for both the mother and the baby if left untreated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Routine antenatal screening does not include echocardiography for cardiac disease unless there is a known or suspected condition.

 

Ref: Page no 110, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?

 

1. Iliococcygeus

2. Pubococcygeus

3. Obturator internus

4. Deep transverse perenei

(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani. The pelvic diaphragm is a muscular partition that separates the pelvic cavity above from the perineum below. It consists of two paired muscles, the levator ani and the coccygeus (also known as the ischiococcygeus or the pubococcygeus), and their fascial coverings.

 

The levator ani muscle is a broad, thin muscle that forms the floor of the pelvic cavity. It consists of three parts: the pubococcygeus, the iliococcygeus, and the puborectalis.

 

  • Pubococcygeus muscle is the most medial of the three, and it arises from the pubic bone and the fascia covering the obturator internus muscle.
  • Iliococcygeus muscle arises from the fascia covering the obturator internus muscle and the ischial spine.
  • Puborectalis muscle is a sling-like muscle that forms a loop around the anorectal junction, and it arises from the pubic bone.

 

The coccygeus muscle is a small, triangular muscle that lies posterior to the levator ani muscle. It arises from the ischial spine and the sacrospinous ligament and inserts onto the coccyx.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. The obturator internus forms the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa and is not a part of the levator ani.

 

Option D. The deep transverse perineal muscle is the content of the deep perineal space and contributes to the formation of the perineal body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles, which are part of the levator ani muscle group. These muscles, including the puborectalis and coccygeus, contribute to the floor of the pelvic cavity and provide structural support, separating the pelvic cavity above from the perineum below.

questions.text:
An internist in India is seeing a patient from a minority cultural and linguistic group. To foster therapeutic alliance and provide the best care possible, which of the following approaches should the physician prioritize? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Insist on good communication.
  2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter.
  3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions.
  4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4

 

To foster a strong therapeutic alliance and provide high-quality care, the physician should prioritize the following:

 

1. Insist on good communication: Effective communication is crucial for building a strong doctor-patient relationship. Good communication helps in understanding the patient's concerns, explaining medical conditions and treatment options clearly, and ensuring that the patient feels heard and respected.

4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception: Culturally competent care involves acknowledging and respecting the patient's cultural, religious, and linguistic background. This approach ensures that care is tailored to meet the specific needs and values of the patient, which can enhance their comfort and trust in the healthcare system.

 

Other Options:

 

2: Incorrect. While good communication is essential, insisting on communication only via an interpreter may not always be necessary or preferred by the patient.

 

3: Incorrect. Treating patients regardless of their cultural perceptions does not align with providing culturally competent care, which aims to respect and incorporate cultural differences into the care plan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The communication skills of physicians are an effective step of making effective relationship between doctor and patient
  • Research has shown that the way patients perceive their connection with their physician significantly influences their sense of satisfaction and level of concern about their health
  • The goal of culturally competent health care services is to provide the highest quality of care to every patient, regardless of race, ethnicity, cultural background

choices.text: Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer is seeking advice about her risk for developing breast cancer. She is currently taking oral contraceptive pills and is concerned about her risk. Which of the following is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

 

  • A family history of breast and ovarian cancer in close relatives with one of the relatives having an onset before the age of 50 years indicates a high risk for breast cancer.
  • The next step in management is genetic counselling and screening for BRA.
  • This involves discussing various genetic testing options such as BRCA testing and multiple gene panel testing.
  • Genetic testing is recommended for high-risk women with a family history of breast or ovarian cancer, particularly if the diagnosis was made before age 50, if there are multiple affected family members, or if the patient has a personal history of breast or ovarian cancer.
  • Mammography is not the initial investigation of choice but can be used for surveillance after genetic screening.
  • Discontinuing oral contraceptive pills is not necessary as they do not increase the risk of breast cancer in women with a positive family history of breast cancer.

 

Given the patient's family history of breast and ovarian cancer, as well as her concerns about her risk, the next best step is to offer genetic counseling and testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations. These genetic mutations are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancer. Understanding her genetic risk can help the patient make informed decisions about her healthcare, including potential surveillance and risk-reduction strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Routine mammography: Routine mammography is a screening tool for breast cancer, but it is typically recommended for women starting at around age 40 or 50, depending on guidelines and individual risk factors. While it's an important part of breast cancer screening, it may not be the most appropriate initial step in this case, given the patient's family history and concerns.

 

Option C. Stop taking oral contraceptive pills: While hormonal factors can be associated with a slight increase in breast cancer risk, discontinuing oral contraceptive pills may not be the primary step in managing a patient with a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer. Genetic counseling and testing for BRCA mutations would provide more specific information about her risk.

 

Option D. Prophylactic surgery: Prophylactic surgery, such as a bilateral mastectomy or oophorectomy, may be considered in individuals with known BRCA mutations who have a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer. However, this step would be taken after genetic counseling and testing to determine the patient's risk and suitability for such procedures. It is not the initial step in management.

questions.text: Researcher was studying the effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and change in pH on ventilation, when he simulated the condition of hypoxia and hypercapnia with pH of 7.35 and plotted the graph, which one of the following is the appropriate representation of the given condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

 

  • Curve A shows linear relationship between PCO2 and Ventilation i.e hypercapnia (↑PCO2) → ↑ Ventilation
  • Curve B shows effect of hypoxia and hypercapnia on Ventilation i.e when both Hypercapnia and Hypoxia (↑PCO2 & ↓O2) are present simultaneously but the pH is normal (unchanged)à slope of the curve also changes hence as a result curve becomes Steeper
  • Curve C shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis on Ventilation i.e. when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (↑PCO2, ↓O2, ↓pH) are present simultaneously → not only the slope of the curve changes but also the Shift of Apneic Point (point denoting PCO2 Levels Below which apnea i.e stoppage of breathing occurs) is seen.
  • Curve D also shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis on Ventilation i.e., when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (↑PCO2, ↓O2, ↓pH) are more severe à the slope of the curve will be more steeper with the Shift of Apneic Point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Curve B represents the condition of simultaneous hypoxia and hypercapnia with normal pH, showing a steeper slope in the relationship between PCO2 and ventilation.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses exhibits genetic re-assortment similar to that of influenza virus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Rotavirus exhibit genetic reassortment similar to that of influenza virus.

 

Rotaviruses - Cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. Genome consists of double-stranded RNA with 11 segments. Segmented RNA helps in easy reassortment of the genome.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Adenovirus can be identified by their icosahedral symmetry with and fibers extruding from the vertices. It is a double stranded DNA virus.

 

 

Option C. Ebola viruses are cylindrical/tubular, and contain viral envelope, matrix, and nucleocapsid components. The virus generally appears in a long, filamentous form, but it can also be “U-shaped,” in the shape of a “6” (the “shepherd’s crook” appearance), or even circular. It is non-segmented and contains single stranded RNA.

 

 

Option D. Rabies viruses belong to Rhabdoviridae which are bullet-shaped viruses with unsegmented single-stranded RNA

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Rotaviruses have a segmented RNA genome that allows them to undergo genetic reassortment similar to influenza viruses.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a first-line drug for the management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Azathioprine

 

The first-line drugs for the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are typically Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs), which include sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate. These drugs are considered core therapies and are often used together in what is known as "triple therapy."

 

Sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate are highly effective and commonly used in the treatment of RA. They form the backbone of conventional synthetic DMARDs (csDMARDs).

 

Azathioprine, on the other hand, is not a first-line drug for RA management. While it is used in some autoimmune conditions, it is not as effective for RA as the other mentioned drugs. Its efficacy is lower, and it is not commonly included in the standard RA treatment regimens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulfasalazine: This drug is a part of the core therapies for RA and is commonly used as a first-line treatment. It is known for its effectiveness and is often used in combination with other DMARDs.

 

Option B. Hydroxychloroquine: Another key first-line drug for RA, hydroxychloroquine is widely used due to its efficacy and relatively favorable safety profile. It is often part of the triple therapy regimen.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is considered the cornerstone of RA treatment and is usually the first drug prescribed. It is highly effective and forms the basis of most RA treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Azathioprine is not a first-line drug for the management of rheumatoid arthritis; the primary first-line drugs are sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate.

 

Note -

 

  • Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine are considered safe for use during pregnancy and are preferred in the management of RA among pregnant patients.
  • Azathioprine is also somewhat safe during pregnancy, but it is not as effective for RA, so it is less preferred compared to Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine.
  • Methotrexate and Leflunomide are not safe for use during pregnancy and should be avoided due to potential risks to the developing fetus.

 

Additional Information:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis management: Range of biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (bDMARDs) and targeted synthetic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (tsDMARDs).

questions.text:
Which of the following has familial inheritance? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Retinoblastoma
  2. Retinitis pigmentosa
  3. Муоріа
  4. Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

All the above conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) have a familial inheritance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma, Retinitis pigmentosa, Myopia, and Primary open-angle glaucoma — exhibit familial inheritance patterns, meaning they can be passed down through families, indicating genetic influences.

questions.text: Which of the following is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genomic imprinting

 

Genomic Imprinting is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents.

 

Important functional differences exist between the paternal allele and the maternal allele. These differences result from an epigenetic process, called imprinting. In most cases, imprinting selectively inactivates either the maternal or paternal allele. Thus, maternal imprinting refers to transcriptional silencing of the maternal allele, whereas paternal imprinting implies that the paternal allele is inactivated.

 

Genomic imprinting is a process of silencing genes through DNA methylation. The repressed allele is methylated, while the active allele is unmethylated.

 

E.g., Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome. Both of these syndromes can be caused by imprinting or other errors involving genes on the long arm of chromosome 15.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadal mosaicism: Gonadal mosaicism refers to the presence of more than one genetically distinct cell line within the gonads. This can lead to different genetic outcomes in offspring but does not involve the differential effect of the same gene based on parental origin. Therefore, it is not related to genomic imprinting.

 

Option C. Anticipation: Anticipation is a phenomenon where a genetic disorder appears earlier and with increased severity in successive generations. This is different from genomic imprinting, as it does not involve the differential effects of a gene based on whether it is inherited from the mother or the father.

 

Option D. Incomplete penetrance: Incomplete penetrance occurs when not all individuals carrying a disease-causing mutation exhibit the disease phenotype. This concept is unrelated to the differential effect of a gene based on its parental origin and does not describe genomic imprinting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic process where the same gene can have different effects depending on whether it is inherited from the mother or the father, typically through mechanisms like DNA methylation.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 328

questions.text: A patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain. A stool examination was done, and it showed the presence of the organism shown in image A. The body has segments broader than the length. Which of the eggs shown in column B corresponds to this organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given image shows characteristic features of Hymenolepis nana. This can be identified by its body segments being broader than long.

 

The egg of hymenolepis nana is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore with 6 hooklets as seen in the image. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: For the prevention of typhoid most important step is immunization
Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, and personal hygiene is more important than immunization
Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that of TB
Person to person transmission is present in 10% of cases

questions.text: During a community health education session, an MBBS student is discussing the prevention of Typhoid Fever. Which of the following statements best captures the primary measures for preventing the transmission of Typhoid in the community? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, personal hygiene is more important than immunization

 

  • The control of typhoid fever must be through improved sanitation and domestic/ personal hygiene.
  • Complementary approaches to prevention include immunization which is the only specific preventive measure likely to provide highest benefit for the money spent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. For the prevention of typhoid most important step is immunization: Incorrect. While important, immunization is not the most critical step compared to improving sanitation and hygiene.

 

Option C. Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that of TB: Incorrect. This statement is unrelated to primary prevention measures for typhoid.

 

Option D. Person to person transmission is present in 10% of cases: Incorrect. Person-to-person transmission is not a significant mode of transmission for typhoid compared to the ingestion of contaminated food or water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary measures for preventing the transmission of Typhoid Fever in the community include proper disposal of feces, a safe water supply, and personal hygiene.
  • These measures are more important than immunization for controlling the spread of the disease.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with lesion in tibial diaphysis. Histopathological examination is shown in below given image. On IHC, it was MIC-2 positive and synaptophysin positive cells. Most likely diagnosis will be: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma

 

EWING SARCOMA

 

  • Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. 

  • Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life.

  • Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. 

  • Diagnosis:

    • Laboratory studies may reveal an increased white blood cell count, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and an elevated C-reactive protein.

    • A needle aspirate may grossly resemble pus.

    • Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. 

 

 

  • The image provided in the question shows a tumor composed of numerous small, relatively uniform, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm. This is the classic "small round blue cell tumor" appearance, which is typical of Ewing sarcoma.

 

  • Markers/Cytogenetics:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is part of a family of peripheral neuroectodermal tumors (PNET) that share a common cytogenetic translocation of chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11:22).

  • MIC2 (CD99) is a specific marker for Ewing's sarcoma and is expressed on short-arm of chromosome x and y. This is a highly characteristic and almost universally positive marker for Ewing sarcoma. It is often used as the primary diagnostic marker.

  • Synaptophysin is more commonly associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but it can be focally positive in some Ewing sarcomas, reflecting its neuroectodermal origin. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma (NB) is the most frequently-occurring extracranial childhood tumor. It is classified as an embryonal neuroendocrine tumor, originating from neural crest progenitor cells. Hence, it can occur anywhere along the sympathetic nervous system, including the superior cervical, paraspinal, and celiac ganglia; the majority arise in the adrenal glands. The most important biological marker is MYCN. Patients with the MYCN gene tend to have rapid progression of cancer and poor outcomes. Other biological markers linked to poor prognosis include lack of expression of glycoprotein CD 44, elevated levels of telomerase RNA, elevated levels of LDH, serum ferritin, and serum neuron-specific enolase. 90% patients have elevations in vanillyl mandelic acid and homovanillic acid in the urine. Histopathology reveal small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (in 10-15% cases), with clustering of cells in the connective tissue. 

 

 

Small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance. Histologically, osteoid production from the tumor cells is seen, presenting as calcification. 

 

 

Codman’s triangle 

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever and nuchal rigidity. The resident was instructed to perform a lumbar puncture on this patient. What is the correct order of managing this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h
  2. Start injection ceftriaxone
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis
  4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 2

 

When managing a patient with fever and nuchal rigidity (suggesting possible meningitis), the correct order of steps is:

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h: Establishing IV access is the first priority to ensure hydration and create a route for medication administration.
  2. 4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture: The lumbar puncture should be performed early to collect CSF samples before antimicrobial therapy alters the CSF findings.
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis: Once the CSF is collected, it must be promptly sent for laboratory analysis to identify potential pathogens and guide targeted therapy.
  4. Start injection ceftriaxone: After CSF collection, empiric antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone should be initiated. This ensures that treatment doesn't interfere with CSF culture results while still providing timely antimicrobial coverage.

 

This sequence prioritizes obtaining diagnostic samples before starting antimicrobial therapy, which is critical for accurate diagnosis while not unduly delaying treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected meningitis, the ideal sequence is to secure samples for microbiological diagnosis before starting antibiotics, when clinically feasible. However, if there will be a significant delay in performing the lumbar puncture or if the patient is critically ill, antibiotics should not be delayed. The sequence emphasizes balancing the need for accurate diagnosis with timely intervention.

questions.text: Which of the below agents cause hypertension when consumed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cocaine

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphorus: Organophosphorus compounds are cholinesterase inhibitors and cause cholinergic symptoms like bradycardia, hypotension, salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, and emesis (SLUDGE syndrome). They do not cause hypertension.

 

Option B. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning typically leads to gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, diarrhea), jaundice, hepatic and renal failure. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning can cause a range of symptoms including gastrointestinal distress, peripheral neuropathy, skin changes (rain drop pigmentation), Mees' lines on nails, and long-term effects like cancer. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and cardiovascular system as mentioned below:

 

  • Agitation and Restlessness
  • Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated Pupils
  • Profuse Sweating
  • Hyperthermia
  • Restlessness
  • Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • Serious Cardiovascular Effects: Arrhythmias, Myocardial Infarction
  • Respiratory Distress: Rapid, shallow breathing and respiratory distress.
  • Seizures, Confusion and Altered Mental Status

questions.text: All of the following conditions are caused by high-risk strains of Human Papilloma virus except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papillomatosis

 

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is not caused by high-risk HPV strains but by low-risk HPV strains (6 and 11).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: Caused by high-risk HPV strains, particularly HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. Anal carcinoma: Also associated with high-risk HPV strains, including HPV 16.

 

Option C. Oropharyngeal carcinoma: Linked to high-risk HPV strains, notably HPV 16.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is caused by low-risk HPV strains (6 and 11) and not by the high-risk strains associated with cancers such as cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 563

questions.text:
You are expected to produce a protein of interest. Arrange the following steps in a sequence.

 

  1. Lysis of bacterial cell
  2. Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria
  3. SDS-PAGE
  4. Hybridization
  5. Protein elution/extraction
  6. Expression of protein

(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) b-f-a-c-d-e

 

Explanation:

 

The steps of Recombinant DNA technology for expressing a gene of interest for production of a desired protein in E. coli cell.

 

The steps of Recombinant DNA technology are:

 

  1. b) Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria: The gene of interest is inserted into a vector such as a plasmid, which is then introduced into the host E. coli cell to produce recombinant E. coli.
  2. f) Expression of protein: The recombinant E. coli is grown in a suitable medium to express the protein inside the cells.
  3. a) Lysis of bacterial cell: The bacterial cells are lysed to extract the expressed protein.
  4. c) SDS-PAGE: The extracted protein is purified using SDS-PAGE electrophoresis.
  5. d) Hybridization: The protein is identified and confirmed by western blotting or hybridization.
  6. e) Protein elution/extraction: Finally, the protein is eluted or extracted for subsequent use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

References: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 432-438

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing district data to determine which areas should be prioritized for tuberculosis (TB) interventions. According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), which of the following HIV-TB prevalence rates would categorize a district as high-priority? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) >10%

 

  • According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), districts are categorized based on specific criteria to prioritize TB interventions.
  • One of these criteria is the prevalence of HIV-TB co-infection.
  • High HIV-TB Prevalence: A district is categorized as high-priority if more than 10% of TB patients tested are known to be HIV positive.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The cell marked in the image below is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mast cell

 

The marked cell is Mast cell which is stained deep blue with Toluidine blue.

 

 

Mast cells are a part of innate immunity and these cells are responsible for the allergic or hypersensitivity reactions.

 

When an antigen binds to IgE antibodies on the surface of the mast cell, they get activated and degranulation occurs releasing various mediators like Histamine, chymase, tryptase, heparin, Lipid mediators (Leukotriene C4, D4), prostaglandin D2, platelet-activating factor cytokines (TNF, IL 1).

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to have endemic transmission in India? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a widespread disease caused by a tick-borne virus (Nairovirus) of the Bunyaviridae family. The CCHF virus causes severe viral haemorrhagic fever outbreaks, with a case fatality rate of 10–40%.

 

CCHF is endemic in Africa, the Balkans, the Middle East and Asian countries south of the 50th parallel north – the geographical limit of the principal tick vector. Outbreak in Gujarat, India occurred in 2011.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow fever is mostly endemic to the south and central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Option C. Ebola virus is located mainly in sub-Saharan Africa

 

Option D. Hendra virus mainly confined to north-eastern coast of Australia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has been reported to have endemic transmission in India, specifically with an outbreak in Gujarat in 2011.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with 15 days of fever and altered sensorium for 1 day. A rapid diagnostic test was done, and Plasmodium falciparum was diagnosed. Which of the following is not a complication? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial pH >7.2

 

An arterial pH >7.2, however, is not considered a complication of severe malaria. In fact, severe acidosis is defined by an arterial pH of less than 7.25, and it is a sign of severe malaria. Therefore, an arterial pH >7.2 does not indicate severe malaria.

 

Other Options:

 

Plasmodium falciparum malaria is a severe form of malaria that can lead to numerous complications. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines several criteria for severe malaria, many of which are seen in complicated cases of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

 

Option A. Blood glucose <40 mg/dL: Severe hypoglycemia is a known complication of severe malaria, particularly in patients treated with quinine.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine - 5.2: This indicates severe renal impairment. Serum creatinine levels above 3 mg/dL or reduced urine output despite rehydration are markers of severe malaria.

 

Option D. Unarousable coma: Cerebral malaria, which includes unarousable coma or seizures, is one of the most severe complications of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic criteria for identifying complicated falciparum malaria, based on clinical and laboratory findings:

 

  1. Arterial pH: An arterial pH of less than 7.25 is indicative of complicated falciparum malaria.
  2. Bicarbonate Levels: A bicarbonate level of less than 15 is also a sign of complicated falciparum malaria.
  3. Base Deficit: A base deficit of more than 8 is another indicator of severe disease.
  4. Hemoglobin: A hemoglobin level of less than 5, or the presence of hemoglobinuria, are significant markers of severity.
  5. Venous Lactate: A venous lactate level of more than 5 further confirms the complexity and severity of the malaria infection.
  6. Blood Glucose: A blood glucose level less than 40 mg/dL is a critical indicator of complicated falciparum malaria.
  7. Creatinine Levels: A creatinine level exceeding 3 mg/dL points to significant renal impairment associated with severe malaria.
  8. Urine Output: A urine output of less than 400 mL per day, despite adequate rehydration with IV fluids, also signifies complicated falciparum malaria.

choices.text: Temperature >38 degree Celsius or <36 degree Celsius

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of fever, increased respiratory rate, elevated heart rate, and low blood pressure. The physician suspects the patient may have SIRS. Which of the following is not a criteria for SIRS? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg.

 

SIRS is diagnosed when two or more of the following criteria are present: hyperthermia or hypothermia, Tachypnea or low PaCO2, Tachycardia, and abnormal white blood cell count. Systolic blood pressure is not included in the SIRS criteria. Sepsis is defined as SIRS with a documented infection.

 

This is not a criterion for SIRS. SIRS criteria typically include fever or hypothermia, tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute), tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute), and abnormal white blood cell count. Low blood pressure is more related to septic shock, which can be a consequence of severe sepsis but is not one of the primary criteria for SIRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature >38 degrees Celsius or <36 degrees Celsius: This is a criterion for SIRS.

 

Option C. Respiratory rate >20 bpm: This is a criterion for SIRS. Elevated respiratory rate (>20 breaths per minute) or paCO2 < 32 mm of Hg is one of the criteria used to diagnose SIRS.

 

Option D. Heart rate >90 min: This is a criterion for SIRS. Tachycardia, defined as a heart rate greater than 90 beats per minute, is one of the key criteria for SIRS.

 

In summary, Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg (option A) is not a criterion for SIRS, while the other options (B, C, and D) are all criteria for SIRS.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dimercaprol

 

Dimercaprol is a traditional chelating agent of choice for acute arsenic poisoning. Though now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Amongst the given choices, dimercaprol is best answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ipecac: Ipecac is rapidly acting anti-emetic. Earlier it was sometimes used to remove different types of unabsorbed poisons in GIT, but now it is no longer recommended due to limited benefits

 

Option B. Penicillamine: Though it can be used in arsenic, but not a preferred agent. It is preferred chelator for copper.

 

Option C. Activated charcoal: Not useful as it does not adsorb arsenic and other heavy metals

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Acute Arsenic poisoning

 

  • Hemodynamic stabilization for significant GI losses (vomiting and diarrhea)
  • Gastric lavage is done repeatedly with large amount of warm water and milk;
  • Chelating Agents
    • Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning
    • There are three chelating agents useful in acute arsenic poisoning:
      1. British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity.
      2. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally
      3. Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.

questions.text:
Which diagnostic investigation is utilized to identify the condition characterized by a 40-year-old man displaying abrupt erythematous painful lesions on the trunk and face, joint pain, and glove and stock anesthesia? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Nerve examination
  2. Skin biopsy
  3. Slit skin smear
  4. Mantoux test
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

The clinical scenario points to a case of leprosy. The diagnosis of this condition requires nerve examination, skin biopsy, and a slit skin smear (option B - 1, 2, 3).

 

The clinical presentation described suggests a condition called leprosy or Hansen's disease, which can cause skin lesions, nerve damage resulting in anaesthesia, and joint pain.

 

1. Nerve examination: An essential part of the diagnosis of leprosy involves the examination of nerves for enlargement and tenderness, which can indicate nerve damage due to the disease.

 

2. Skin biopsy: A biopsy of the affected skin can be taken and histologically examined for the presence of Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium that causes leprosy.

 

3. Slit skin smear:  This test involves taking a sample from the skin (usually from the earlobes or from lesions) and staining it for acid-fast bacilli, which is a characteristic of Mycobacterium leprae.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Mantoux test:

 

  • The Mantoux test is used to diagnose tuberculosis, not leprosy.
  • It involves the tuberculin skin test (TST) to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium leprae are both acid-fast bacilli.
  • The Mantoux test is specific for TB and does not directly aid in the diagnosis of leprosy

 

Characteristic clinical features of Hansen’s disease / Leprosy

 

  • Mycobacterium leprae is the cause of the chronic granulomatous disease known as leprosy.
  • The typical incubation period for leprosy is 2 to 12 years.
  • It frequently manifests as a visible skin lesion, such as a hypopigmented or erythematous macule, or as a numb spot on the skin.
  • The face, buttocks, trunk, and extensor aspects of the limbs are frequently affected by lesions.
  • Skin, cutaneous, and peripheral nerves, as well as mucous membranes, are all impacted.
  • The posterior tibial nerve, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves, are the peripheral nerves that are most frequently affected.
  • The facial nerve is the cranial nerve that is involved most frequently.
  • Both nerve function and hair growth are compromised by the lesions.
  • Burns or ulcers on the amputation limb may also be present in the patients.

 

Additional Information

 

Classification systems of leprosy:

 

Ridley-Jopling classification

 

  • Tuberculoid (TT)
  • Borderline tubercular (BT)
  • Borderline (BB)
  • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
  • Lepromatous (LL)

 

WHO classification:

 

  • Paucibacillary
  • Multibacillary

 

Cardinal signs for the diagnosis of leprosy:

 

 

  • The presence of two of the three signs can establish the diagnosis of leprosy. Other tests done for diagnosis of leprosy include nerve biopsy in pure neural leprosy and PGL-1 antibody in cases with low bacterial load.
  • Mantoux test is not useful in diagnosis of leprosy. This is the test which helps to explain the prognosis of leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate diagnostic investigations for a suspected case of leprosy include nerve examination, skin biopsy, and slit skin smear to detect the presence of Mycobacterium leprae and to assess the extent of nerve damage.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 28 page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition 1385, 1386, 1388

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient weighing 60 kg is on mechanical ventilation for ARDS secondary to urosepsis. The respiratory parameters are as follows: tidal volume- 360 mL; frequency- 30 breaths/min; PEEP- 5 cm of H2O; and FiO2- 90%. The arterial blood gas findings are as follows: paO2- 50 mmHg; paCO2- 38 mmHg and pH- 7.38. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase PEEP

 

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) requires careful management of mechanical ventilation settings to optimize oxygenation while minimizing lung injury. The patient's current settings and blood gas findings suggest hypoxemia (paO2 of 50 mmHg) with an FiO2 of 90%. The goal in managing ARDS is to maintain adequate oxygenation (paO2 > 60 mmHg) while reducing the FiO2 to less than 60% to avoid oxygen toxicity.

 

Increasing PEEP is the best option to improve oxygenation. PEEP helps to keep alveoli open, improving gas exchange and oxygenation. By increasing PEEP, we can potentially increase the paO2 and eventually reduce the FiO2 to safer levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduce FiO2: Although reducing FiO2 is a long-term goal to prevent oxygen toxicity, it is not advisable to reduce it immediately because the patient is currently hypoxemic (paO2 of 50 mmHg).

 

Option B. Increase tidal volume: Not appropriate as it can increase the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury in ARDS patients. The current tidal volume is within the safe range (360 mL), which is appropriate for a 60 kg patient as it falls within the recommended range of 4-6 mL/kg for ARDS patients to prevent ventilator-induced lung injury.

 

Option C. Increase respiratory rate: Increasing the respiratory rate is not necessary in this situation as the paCO2 (38 mmHg) and pH (7.38) indicate normal ventilation and no significant respiratory acidosis (paCO2 is normal).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS management, if the patient remains hypoxemic despite a high FiO2, the next step is to increase the PEEP to improve oxygenation while maintaining lung-protective ventilation strategies.

questions.text:
Which of the following are a part of the limbic system?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Amygdala

2. Hippocampus

3. Thalamus
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

The limbic system is a complex set of brain structures located on both sides of the thalamus, immediately beneath the cerebrum. It includes key components such as the amygdala, hippocampus, thalamus, hypothalamus, basal ganglia, and cingulate gyrus. These structures support a variety of functions related to emotions, behavior, motivation, long-term memory, and olfaction.

 

  1. Amygdala: Integral for processing emotions, the amygdala is especially involved in fear, anxiety, and social cognition. It also plays a significant role in forming and retrieving emotional memories.
  2. Hippocampus: Essential for learning and memory, the hippocampus is pivotal in the consolidation of information from short-term memory to long-term memory and spatial navigation.
  3. Thalamus: Although primarily known as the relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, the thalamus also supports functions of the limbic system by regulating consciousness, sleep, and alertness.

 

Other structures are :

 

The hypothalamus is involved in regulating many bodily functions, including hunger, thirst, body temperature, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a key role in the regulation of the autonomic nervous system and the endocrine system.

 

The cingulate gyrus is involved in a variety of functions, including emotion regulation, attention, and the processing of pain.

 

Together, these structures form a complex network that plays a crucial role in many aspects of human behavior and cognition. Dysfunction or damage to the limbic system can lead to a range of neurological and psychiatric disorders, including Alzheimer's disease, depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The limbic system’s role is critical, as its structures are deeply integrated into the processes governing emotions, memory, and essential physiological functions. Damage or dysfunction in any part of the limbic system can lead to profound psychological and cognitive impairments, affecting everything from emotional regulation to memory processing.

choices.text: It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years
Type 1 is common in both sexes
Attempt to commit suicide is seen around 15% of people

questions.text: Which of the following is false about bipolar disorder? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years

 

Bipolar disorder, historically called manic-depressive illness, often begins in late adolescence or early adulthood. While it can start in childhood or later in life, this is less common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 1 is common in both sexes: True. Bipolar I disorder has no gender bias and affects men and women equally.

 

Option C. Prevalence in the general population is 1-2%: True. Bipolar disorder affects about 1-2% of the global population.

 

Option D. Attempt to commit suicide is seen in around 15% of people: True. People with bipolar disorder have a high suicide risk, and approximately 15% may end up taking their own life.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bipolar disorder typically presents in late adolescence or early adulthood. It is characterized by episodes of mania and depression, affects both sexes equally, has a prevalence of 1-2% in the general population, and carries a significant risk of suicide.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 376.

questions.text: DNA-Protein interactions can be studied by using: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNA footprinting

 

  • DNA footprinting is a technique used to study DNA-protein interactions. It involves the selective cleavage or modification of DNA sequences by a DNA-binding protein. By analyzing the resulting pattern of cleavage or modification, researchers can determine which regions of the DNA are bound by the protein, effectively "footprinting" its interaction sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA fingerprinting: DNA fingerprinting is a technique used to identify individuals based on their unique DNA patterns, primarily in the context of forensic science and paternity testing. It is not specifically used to study DNA-protein interactions.

 

Option C. Northern Blotting: Northern blotting is a molecular biology technique used to study gene expression by analyzing the presence and quantity of specific RNA molecules in a sample. It is not primarily used to study DNA-protein interactions but rather RNA-related processes.
