Option D. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): ELISA is an immunological assay used to detect the presence of specific antibodies or antigens in a sample. While it can indirectly provide information about protein-protein interactions, it is not a direct method for studying DNA-protein interactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA footprinting is the appropriate method for studying DNA-Protein interactions, as it allows researchers to identify the specific binding sites of proteins on DNA by selectively cleaving or modifying the DNA sequence. This technique is fundamental for understanding how proteins interact with DNA in various biological processes.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 451

choices.text: Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations

questions.text: What are the potential observations that could be observed in this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of sensation over foot

 

In this case, the patient is likely to have a neuropathic/trophic ulcer, which is characterized by a lack of sensation over the foot due to peripheral neuropathy. These ulcers are painless and have punched-out margins with the presence of calluses. The ulcer is located on the plantar surface of the foot (weight bearing area). The other options, such as decreased pulsations in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries, positive Trendelenburg sign, and pain on compression of calf, are not likely to be seen in this patient with a neuropathic ulcer.

 

Loss of sensation over the foot can lead to neuropathic/trophic ulcers as seen above. This is usually seen in neuropathies like Diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations: Decreased or absent posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulsations are indicative of vascular compromise or reduced blood flow to the lower extremity. This can lead to ischemic ulcers which are seen at tips of toes, web spaces, dorsum of foot etc. The image does not suggest an ischemic ulcer.

 

Option C. Positive Trendelenberg test: This is seen in varicose veins with saphenofemoral incompetence, and may have varicose ulcers above medial malleolus (Gaiter’s area). The image is not a case of varicose ulcer.

 

Option D. Pain on compression of calf: Pain on compression of the calf may indicate a potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to calf pain and swelling and venous ulcers. The image is not a case of DVT with venous ulcer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of sensation over the foot is a potential observation that could be observed in a patient with neuropathic/trophic ulcers.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of an old lady who sustained a fall and presented with a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subdural Hematoma

 

The given clinical scenario suggests Acute Subdural Hematoma (SDH), which is the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura, resulting from the tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the Dural sinuses. It is commonly seen in the elderly, alcoholics, and patients on anticoagulants. The stretching of Cortical-Dural bridging veins in cerebral atrophy makes them vulnerable to rupture, leading to symptoms of raised intracranial pressure or focal deficits. On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion.

 

A subdural hematoma is a collection of blood between the layers of the dura mater surrounding the brain. It can occur as a result of head trauma, such as a fall, and may not present with immediate symptoms but can lead to a gradual onset of neurological symptoms, including headache, confusion, and other focal neurological deficits. Subdural hematomas are known to have delayed presentations after the initial trauma, making this the likely diagnosis in the context of a fall with subsequent neurological symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multi-infarct dementia: Multi-infarct dementia, also known as vascular dementia, typically develops gradually and is associated with a history of multiple strokes or cerebral infarctions. It does not typically present acutely after a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe meningioma: While a frontal lobe meningioma can cause neurological symptoms, it typically develops slowly and is not usually associated with an acute presentation following a fall. Additionally, the symptoms of a meningioma can vary widely depending on its location and size.

 

Option C. Korsakoff disease: Korsakoff disease is primarily associated with chronic alcohol abuse and is characterized by severe memory impairment. It does not typically present acutely following a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the history of a fall and the delayed onset of neurological symptoms, a subdural hematoma (option D) is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in chronic arsenic poisoning except? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Luminous vomit

 

Luminous vomiting is a feature of yellow phosphorus poisoning, not arsenic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Raindrop pigmentation: This is a characteristic skin finding in chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Option B. Peripheral neuritis: Peripheral neuritis is a common neurological manifestation of chronic arsenic exposure.

 

Option C. Mees line: Mees lines (transverse white lines on nails) are indicative of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features seen in chronic arsenic poisoning:

 

1. Peripheral neuropathy (neuritis):         

It can occur in Arsenic , Thallium , Mercury, and Lead.                                  

Lead: Mainly motor, little bit sensory neuropathy                                                     

Arsenic, Thallium, mercury: mainly sensory, little bit motor neuropathy 

 

2) Skin symptoms:

- Hypopigmentation initially

- Rain Drop Pigmentation as shown below

 

 

- Peculiar skin rash – resembles Addison’s disease , Fading measles rash

- Hyperkeratosis of palms & soles as shown below:

 

3) Nails: Aldrich Mees Lines

Transverse whitish lines on nails (seen is Arsenic, and Thallium)

 

 

 

4) Hair: Alopecia seen in Mercury, Arsenic, Thallium (Mnemonic: Hair on MAT)

 

5) GIT: Vomiting , Diarrhoea , pain abdomen

 

6) Liver: Jaundice , Hepatomegaly , Fatty liver , Cirrhosis

 

7) Blackfoot disease: Coagulation in Peripheral blood vessels leading to Gangrene of periphery

 

8) Malignancy of almost any body part

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Human genome project?  (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It took 2 years to discover

 

  • Explanation: Option D is false. The Human Genome Project did not take only 2 years to complete. It was a long-term endeavor that spanned over a decade. The official launch of the project was in 1990, and a working draft of the human genome was announced in 2000. The project was completed in 2003.
  • Relevance: This statement is false, and the actual timeline of the Human Genome Project demonstrates that it was a multi-year, collaborative effort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collaboration of Many Countries:

 

  • Explanation: The Human Genome Project was indeed a collaborative effort involving many countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Japan, and others. It aimed to map and sequence the entire human genome.
  • Relevance: This statement is true and reflects the international nature of the project.

 

Option B. 20,000 Total Genes Were Identified :

 

  • Explanation: During the Human Genome Project, it was estimated that there are approximately 20,000-25,000 protein-coding genes in the human genome. This estimate is relatively accurate, considering the complexity of the human genome.
  • Relevance: This statement is true and reflects one of the significant achievements of the HGP.

 

Option C. It Uses Modern Sequencing Techniques:

 

Explanation: 

 

  • The project initially started with Sanger sequencing, which was state-of-the-art at the time.
  • Towards the end and afterward, next-generation sequencing (NGS) evolved, further enhancing genome studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The project initially started with Sanger sequencing, which was state-of-the-art at the time.


Towards the end and afterward, next-generation sequencing (NGS) evolved, further enhancing genome studies.
 

Reference: Harper’s 30th ed/pg- 98

questions.text: Eicosanoids are formed from:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arachidonic acid

 

Eicosanoids are derived from arachidonic acid, which is a polyunsaturated fatty acid found in cell membranes. Arachidonic acid serves as the precursor for eicosanoid synthesis when it is released from membrane phospholipids through the action of enzymes such as phospholipase A2. Once released, arachidonic acid can be metabolized into various eicosanoids, including prostaglandins, leukotrienes, and thromboxanes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelet aggregation: Platelet aggregation refers to the process of blood platelets clumping together. While eicosanoids can influence platelet aggregation by promoting or inhibiting it, they are not formed directly from platelet aggregation. Platelet aggregation involves the activation of platelets and the release of various signaling molecules, including some eicosanoids, as part of the clotting process.

 

Option C. 4 fused rings: Eicosanoids are not characterized by having four fused rings. Instead, they are typically small molecules with a 20-carbon backbone structure.

 

Option D. Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid and is not directly involved in the formation of eicosanoids. Eicosanoids are primarily derived from arachidonic acid, as mentioned earlier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eicosanoids are bioactive lipid molecules that play a crucial role in various physiological processes in the body. They are formed from arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid has (20 C, 4=) and is synthesized from linoleic acid. Eicosanoids (Prostaglandins and leukotrienes) are synthesized from arachidonic acid. So, Linoleic acid is considered as most essential fatty acid.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 224

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient underwent hernia surgery and complained of a loss of sensations over the root of his penis during his postoperative recovery. The patient reported no prior history of genital trauma or surgery. Which of the following nerves would you suspect to be the cause of the patient's loss of sensation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ilioinguinal nerve

 

The ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely nerve to be implicated in this scenario. It provides sensation to the skin over the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum, and can be injured during inguinal hernia repair surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Iliohypogastric nerve: The Iliohypogastric nerve carries sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve rarely causes sensory disturbances in the right iliac fossa due to the rich nerve supply from other sources. However, severing this nerve above the anterior superior iliac spine can lead to weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal, resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. Injury to this nerve can also occur following appendicectomy.

 

Option C. The genitofemoral nerve: The genitofemoral nerve has a genital branch that provides sensation to the scrotum in males and mons pubis and labia majora in females. Injury to the genital branch can cause loss of sensation in these areas.

 

The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament, but this is not relevant to the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh: The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh a sensory branch of the femoral nerve that supplies sensation to the anterior-medial aspect of the thigh and knee. Injury to this nerve can lead to loss of sensation in these areas, but is not related to the patient's loss of sensation in the root of the penis.

questions.text: Which of the following graphs represents normal response to OGTT? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Graph D

 

Explanation:

 

The normal response to an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is depicted by Graph D. During an OGTT, a patient ingests a specified amount of glucose (commonly 75 grams), and blood glucose levels are measured at intervals to evaluate how well the body handles glucose. In a normal response:

 

  • Blood glucose levels rise to a peak within 1 hour after ingestion.
  • Glucose levels then decline and return to baseline by 2 hours.
  • The glucose levels do not exceed the renal threshold at any point during the test.

 

This pattern reflects the body's effective regulation of blood glucose levels and the normal function of insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graph A: Graph A might depict an abnormal glucose tolerance curve, such as one seen in impaired glucose tolerance or gestational diabetes, where glucose levels remain elevated for a prolonged period or fail to return to baseline.

 

Option B. Graph B: Graph B could show a response with an abnormal peak or delayed return to baseline, indicative of glucose intolerance or a diagnostic criterion for diabetes mellitus.

 

Option C. Graph C: Graph C might represent an exaggerated glucose peak or prolonged elevated glucose levels, suggesting a pathological glucose tolerance response consistent with diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A normal OGTT response features a peak in blood glucose levels within 1 hour, followed by a return to baseline levels within 2 hours, without exceeding the renal threshold.

 

Ref: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/301045468_VARIANTS_OF_ORAL_GLUCOSE_TOLERANCE_TEST_OGTT_CURVE_IN_GESTATIONAL_DIABETES_MELLITUS_GDM

choices.text: Cytotoxic T cells
B cells
NK cells
Helper cells

questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC class I activates which of the following cells? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cells

 

Cytotoxic T cells: MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens, typically derived from intracellular proteins, to cytotoxic T cells (also known as CD8+ T cells). When a cytotoxic T cell recognizes an antigen presented by MHC class I on the surface of a cell, it is activated to destroy the infected or malignant cell.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. B cells: B cells are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) and by direct interaction with helper T cells (CD4+ T cells), not by MHC class I.

 

Option C. NK cells: Natural Killer (NK) cells do not rely on MHC class I molecules for activation. In fact, they often target cells with low or absent MHC class I expression, which is a common strategy of infected or transformed cells to evade cytotoxic T cells.

 

Option D. Helper cells: Helper T cells (CD4+ T cells) are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on APCs, not by MHC class I.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Which investigation is not necessary for the following condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 24-h pH monitoring

 

24-hr pH monitoring is done in GERD. The above image is suggestive of gradual narrowing in lower esophagus, likely to be achalasia.

 

This is a test that measures the pH of the esophagus over a 24-hour period to assess for abnormal acid reflux. While not typically necessary for the diagnosis of achalasia cardia, 24-hour pH monitoring may be used to rule out gastroesophageal reflux disease as a potential cause of dysphagia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timed barium study: In the case of achalasia cardia, the barium will be retained in the esophagus for more than five minutes and the study may reveal a dilated esophagus with a 'bird's beak' appearance at the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Option B. Endoscopy: Endoscopy may be used to rule out other potential causes of dysphagia, such as esophageal cancer, and to obtain biopsy samples if needed.

 

Option C. Esophageal manometry: This is a diagnostic test that measures the pressure and motility of the esophagus during swallowing. In the case of achalasia cardia, esophageal manometry may reveal incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter in response to swallowing, high resting LES pressure, and absent esophageal peristalsis. It is the test of choice for diagnosis of achalasia.

questions.text: Which biopsy technique is used to diagnose Marjolin ulcer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wedge biopsy

 

Wedge biopsy involves the removal of a small, wedge-shaped piece of tissue from the border of an ulcer. This technique is particularly useful in diagnosing Marjolin ulcers because it is the site where squamous cell carcinomas have maximum proliferation, leading to “everted edge”. Marjolin ulcers often develop in areas of previously injured or scarred skin, and a wedge biopsy can provide a representative sample for histopathological examination to confirm the presence of malignancy.


Other Options:

 

Option B. Excision biopsy: Excision biopsy is the technique of choice for a cervical lymph node pathology, in which the entire lymph node is surgically removed for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Core needle biopsy: Core needle biopsy is preferred for sampling soft tissue sarcomas, in which a small sample of tissue is removed using a large bore needle for examination.

 

Option D. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC): USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the technique of choice for a solitary thyroid nodule, in which a small amount of thyroid tissue is aspirated using a thin needle and examined under a microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A wedge biopsy is the preferred and commonly used biopsy technique to diagnose Marjolin ulcers because it allows for the examination of tissue from the ulceration site.

questions.text: All of the following parameters are true for anemia of chronic disease except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease in serum ferritin

 

Anemia of chronic disease (ACD), also known as anemia of inflammation, is a common type of anemia that occurs in the context of chronic infections (like TB, chronic osteomyelitis), autoimmune diseases (RA,IBD), cancer, and other chronic conditions. It is characterized by several key features related to iron metabolism and the body's response to inflammation.

 

This statement is incorrect. Serum ferritin is an acute-phase reactant, meaning its levels increase in response to inflammation. Therefore, in ACD, serum ferritin levels are typically increased or normal, not decreased. Ferritin acts as a marker of iron stores, and in ACD, iron stores are usually normal or increased, but the iron is not readily available for use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in serum hepcidin: Hepcidin is a peptide hormone produced by the liver that regulates iron homeostasis. In ACD, hepcidin levels are increased due to inflammation. Hepcidin inhibits iron absorption from the gut and the release of iron from macrophages, leading to reduced availability of iron for erythropoiesis.

 

Option C. Associated with conditions like TB: ACD is often associated with chronic infections and inflammatory diseases. The chronic inflammation leads to the production of cytokines like IL-6, which increase hepcidin production and subsequently cause the anemia.

 

Option D. Normal iron stores: Iron stores in ACD are usually normal or increased. The issue in ACD is not the lack of iron but rather the body's inability to utilize the iron effectively due to the inflammatory response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum ferritin levels increase in anemia of chronic disease.

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1234

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson is a 60-year-old woman who underwent a Whipple's procedure for pancreatic cancer three weeks ago. She developed a fever and abdominal pain, and her surgeon suspected a postoperative complication. Which of the following complications causes maximum malnutrition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal fistula

 

  • Among the given conditions, maximum malnutrition is caused by duodenal fistulas.
  • Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified based on their location and volume of daily output.
  • Proximal fistulas have higher output and are associated with greater fluid, electrolyte, and digestive capacity loss.
  • Distal fistulas have lower output and are easier to manage, with a higher likelihood of spontaneous closure.
  • Duodenal fistulas receive an additional 1 to 2 liters of enzymes, electrolytes, and water from the pancreatic and bile ducts, making them more susceptible to electrolyte imbalances than gastric fistulas.
  • The management of enterocutaneous fistulas follows the SNAP principles:
    • S: Sepsis elimination and skin protection
    • N: A period of parenteral nutrition may be required
    • A: Anatomical assessment
    • P: Definitive planned surgery.

 

A duodenal fistula involves a connection between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and an unintended location, such as the abdominal cavity. This can result in severe malnutrition because the duodenum is a critical site for nutrient absorption in the digestive process. A duodenal fistula can lead to the loss of digestive juices and nutrients, significantly impacting a patient's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatic fistula: A pancreatic fistula is a complication where pancreatic fluids leak from the surgical site. While it can lead to malnutrition due to the loss of digestive enzymes, it is not typically as severe as a duodenal fistula in causing malnutrition.

 

Option C. Distal ileal fistula: While a distal ileal fistula can disrupt nutrient absorption to some extent, it is not as critical as a duodenal fistula in terms of causing maximum malnutrition. The ileum is further down the small intestine, and its role in nutrient absorption is not as central as that of the duodenum.

 

Option D. Colonic fistula: A colonic fistula may lead to the loss of stool and fluids but is not primarily responsible for causing severe malnutrition in the same way as a duodenal fistula. The colon's main function is to absorb water and electrolytes, not nutrients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A duodenal fistula (option B) is the postoperative complication that can cause maximum malnutrition due to its disruption of nutrient absorption in the critical site of the digestive process, the duodenum.

choices.text: Yolk sac tumor
Granulosa cell tumor

questions.text: Which of the following tumors shows the following finding? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Yolk sac tumor

 

The image shows the characteristic Schiller Duval body which is consistent with yolk sac tumor.

 

  • Endodermal sinus tumor or yolk sac tumor is the second most common germ cell tumor
  • Frequently seen in children and young women.
  • The tumor is usually unilateral but may metastasise to the other ovary.
  • It is a highly aggressive and rapidly growing tumor.
  • Grossly, the tumor is nonencapsulated, and on cross-section shows homogeneous, yellow-white, mucinous appearance.
  • Characteristic on microscopic examination
    • Lacelike (reticular) network of medium-sized cuboidal or flattened cells.
    • Papillary structures, solid cords of cells, and a multitude of other less common patterns may be found.
    • Schiller-Duval bodies may be seen; these consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli.
    • Present within and outside the cytoplasm are eosinophilic, hyaline-like globules in which α- fetoprotein (AFP) and α1-antitrypsin can be demonstrated by immunocytochemical staining.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminoma (counterpart of seminoma) is a germ cell tumor. Sheets or cords of large clear cells are seen.

 

Option C. Krukenberg tumor: Krukenberg tumor is a secondary ovarian tumor. Characterized by signet ring” mucin-secreting cells.

 

 

Option D. Granulosa cell tumor: Granulosa cell tumor is Composed of mixture of cuboidal granulosa cells and spindled or plump lipid-laden theca cells. Call-Exner bodies are seen.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Schiller-Duval bodies is a key diagnostic feature of yolk sac tumors, distinguishing them from other types of ovarian tumors.

questions.text: The rupture of penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deep perineal pouch

 

Option B. Deep perineal pouch: This is a space situated superior to the perineal membrane and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. It contains the membranous urethra, deep transverse perineal muscles, and parts of the external urethral sphincter. Extravasation of urine is possible in deep perineal pouch.

 

When there is a rupture of the penile urethra (often due to trauma, such as a straddle injury), the extravasation of urine and blood can occur into various anatomical spaces, depending on the location and nature of the injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial perineal pouch: This is a space located in the urogenital triangle of the perineum, bounded above by the perineal membrane and below by the perineal (Colles') fascia. The pouch contains the root of the penis (including the bulb of the penis) and the associated muscles. A rupture of the penile urethra can cause extravasation of urine and blood into this space.

 

Option C. Skin around penis. The skin around base of penis may get involved if the rupture is located in the bulbous part of urethra.

 

Option D. Skin around the scrotum: With a rupture of the penile urethra, especially if the rupture occurs in the bulbous part located within the superficial perineal pouch, the extravasated urine and blood can dissect through the fascial layers and present as swelling and bruising around the scrotum and base of the penis. This is often referred to as a "butterfly" pattern of bruising, as the extravasated fluid can spread anteriorly onto the anterior abdominal wall and laterally to the thighs but is typically limited superiorly by Scarpa's fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

The membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

questions.text: In neonatal resuscitation, which of the following is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rise in heart rate.

 

An increase in heart rate is the best sign that a ventilatory effort is working.

 

When newborns are unable to breathe on their own, positive pressure ventilation, or PP, is used. To ensure that the airway is open, the infant's neck is slightly stretched in this position. An appropriate-sized face mask is chosen so that it may cover the mouth and nose when the care provider is at the baby's head end. For a good seal, it should be gripped firmly, and compression is applied using the fingers.

 

Visible chest rise is a sign of adequate ventilation, and ventilation should be initiated when normal chest rise is seen.

 

The baby's progress is measured by an increase in heart rate, spontaneous breathing, and improvement in colour.

 

When there is no rise in heart rate, ventilation corrective steps should be taken. It is as follows

 

  • Mask has to be reapplied
  • The infant's head is repositioned
  • Suction the secretions
  • The mouth is kept open slightly and ventilated. Also, the pressure is increased slightly.
  • Change the airway

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colour change: Colour change is a component of APGAR score

 

Option C. Air entry: Air entry is checked during intubation to check weather the endotracheal tube is in centre which gives equal air entry to both lungs.

 

Option D. Chest rise: Chest rise is also seen once we do bag and mask ventilation but the most important indicator is rising heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neonatal resuscitation, rise in heart rate is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort.

choices.text: Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume
Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH
Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages
Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

questions.text: All are true about biophysical profile (BPP) except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

 

Explanation:

 

  • BPP score is not inconsistent with fetal pH, but has a direct linear relationship with fetal pH and thus can be used to predict fetal acidemia.
  • BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency.
  • It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period.
  • The Biophysical Profile has 5 components and is scored using Manning score
    • NST
    • Amniotic Fluid Volume
    • Fetal movement
    • Fetal Tone
    • Fetal Breathing

   

 

  • A low Manning score correlates with fetal hypoxia
  • Narcotics and sedatives can significantly lower the score
  • A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH.
  • An equivocal test result—a score of 6—was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome.
  • Overall, BPP scores provided poor sensitivity to predict cord blood pH
  • The Modified BPP has 2 components
    • NST
    • AFI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume: This statement is true. The BPP includes assessments of fetal breathing, movements, tone, and the Amniotic fluid volume as part of its evaluation.

 

Option B. Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH: This statement is true. The BPP score helps predict fetal outcome and provides an indication of fetal pH, reflecting the level of fetal distress.

 

Option D. Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia: This statement is true. A BPP score of less than 4 correlates with a fetal pH <7.2, and a score of 0 is almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) provides a consistent prediction of fetal pH and outcome, with a lower score correlating with increased risk of fetal acidemia.

 

Ref: Page no 999, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

choices.text: If replacement feeding, the neonate should be tested for HIV, if negative, ART is not required.
In exclusive breastfeeding, give nevirapine for 6 months only when baby is positive
If replacement feeding, the neonate need not receive nevirapine if HIV negative
If exclusive replacement feeding, give nevirapine for 6 weeks, even if the baby is negative

questions.text: A pediatrician is providing counselling to a pregnant woman who is HIV positive about postnatal care for her soon-to-be-born child. Which of the following statements best captures the recommended management for an infant born to a mother with HIV regarding antiretroviral treatment (ART)? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) If exclusive replacement feeding, give nevirapine for 6 weeks, even if the baby is negative

 

The baby should be given prophylaxis irrespective of feeding status and HIV status at birth.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. If replacement feeding, the neonate should be tested for HIV, if negative, ART is not required: Incorrect. Prophylaxis with nevirapine should still be given for 6 weeks regardless of HIV status.

 

Option B. In exclusive breastfeeding, give nevirapine for 6 months only when baby is positive: Incorrect. Nevirapine is given as prophylaxis irrespective of the infant's HIV status.

 

Option C. If replacement feeding, the neonate need not receive nevirapine if HIV negative: Incorrect. Prophylaxis should still be provided for 6 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Infants of HIV-positive mothers on exclusive replacement feeding get 6-week nevirapine, regardless of their HIV status.

choices.text: Inside the membrane
At the C-terminal
At the N-terminal
Both inside the membrane and at C- terminal

questions.text: The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein with N-terminal facing cytoplasm is located in?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inside the membrane

 

The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein is located inside the membrane.

 

These sequences usually have methionine as the terminal amino acid.

 

Transmembrane proteins are integral proteins that span across the plasma/ endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane. They are classified into types 1 to 4. –

 

Type 1 membrane proteins have a cleavable N-terminal signal sequence outside the cell, a transmembrane sequence that is usually situated close to the C-terminus and the C-terminus facing inside the cell, e.g., low-density lipoprotein receptor.

 

Type 2 membrane proteins have the N-terminal towards the cytosol and the C-terminal towards the exterior, e.g., transferrin receptor.

 

Type 3 membrane proteins are identical to type 1 but have a shorter N terminal, e.g., cytochrome P450 enzyme complexes.

 

Type 4 membrane proteins consist of 7 alpha helices traversing the membrane, e.g., glucose transporters and G-protein-coupled receptors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. At the C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is not located at the C-terminal.

 

Option C. At the N-terminal: This is incorrect as well. In type 2 membrane proteins, the N-terminal is facing the cytoplasm, but the signaling sequence itself is located inside the membrane.

 

Option D. Both inside the membrane and at C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence is located specifically inside the membrane, not at the C-terminal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is located inside the membrane, crucial for the proper orientation and insertion of the protein.

questions.text: What is the action of the superior oblique muscle? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion, abduction, depression

 

  • The superior oblique muscle is responsible for three actions: intorsion, depression, and abduction.
  • Each eye has six extraocular muscles: four recti muscles and two oblique muscles.
  • The recti muscles are the superior, inferior, medial, and lateral rectus.
  • The superior oblique muscle originates from the apex of the orbit, turns around the trochlea, and inserts into the sclera behind the equator.
  • The tendon's oblique direction gives it a rotator effect, resulting in intorsion, as well as depression and abduction.
  • These muscles control both unilateral and binocular movements of the eye.
  • Unilateral eye movements are called Ductions.
  • Bilateral eye movements are called Versions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Fingerprint develops in how many weeks of intrauterine life? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 12-16

 

Fingerprints begin to form between 12 to 16 weeks of intrauterine life. By this stage, the basic patterns of the ridges on the skin are established. The formation continues, and fingerprints are complete by approximately 24 weeks of intrauterine life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fingerprints start developing between 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life and are completed by 24 weeks, providing a unique identification for the individual that remains unchanged throughout their life.

questions.text: dd-NTPs in Sanger’s Sequencing technique uses? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Termination of polymerase

 

  • The correct answer is C. ddNTPs are used in Sanger's Sequencing because they lack the 3'-OH group required for the formation of the phosphodiester bond during DNA strand elongation. When a ddNTP is incorporated into the growing DNA strand by DNA polymerase, it causes termination of DNA synthesis because the next nucleotide cannot be added due to the absence of the 3'-OH group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its fluorescence: ddNTPs in Sanger's Sequencing are not primarily used for their fluorescence. While modern Sanger Sequencing methods may incorporate fluorescence for detection, ddNTPs themselves are not inherently fluorescent.

 

Option B. DNA polymerization: ddNTPs do not contribute to DNA polymerization in the same way as regular dNTPs (deoxynucleotide triphosphates). Regular dNTPs are used by DNA polymerase to extend the DNA strand, while ddNTPs have a unique property that leads to their specific role in sequencing.

 

Option D. Removal of primer: ddNTPs are not involved in the removal of primers in Sanger's Sequencing. Primer removal typically occurs after the sequencing reaction is complete and is not directly related to the role of ddNTPs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dideoxy nucleotides are nucleotides in which O from 2’ and 3’ position of sugar is absent. These nucleotides, if inserted in the growing DNA chains will cause termination of polymerization as DNA polymerase will not be able to perform catalyzation of formation of Phosphodiester bond. This form the basis for a DNA sequencing technique know as Sanger DNA sequencing aka chain termination method.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 439

questions.text: Which of the following disease is exclusively seen in females? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

 

Rett syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects brain development and results in severe intellectual and physical disability. It is nearly always seen in females. Males with the genetic mutation for Rett syndrome usually die shortly after birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asperger syndrome: It is a milder variant of autism and can occur in both males and females, although it is more commonly diagnosed in males.

 

Option C. Selective mutism: An anxiety disorder in which a person who is normally capable of speech cannot speak in specific situations or to specific people. It affects both males and females.

 

Option D. Atypical autism: Also known as Pervasive Developmental Disorder - Not Otherwise Specified (PDD-NOS), it can occur in both males and females.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurodevelopmental disorder almost exclusively seen in females. It is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene located on the X chromosome. It is characterized by normal development for the first 6-18 months of life followed by a loss of purposeful hand skills, severe language impairment, and motor abnormalities.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 165.

questions.text: A biostatistics professor is teaching a group of medical students about the fundamentals of statistics. She mentions a branch that is specifically concerned with summarizing and presenting data in a meaningful way. Which of the following branches is she most likely referring to? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Descriptive statistics

 

Descriptive Statistics:

 

  • Data is summarised through the given observations; summarisation is done from a sample of population using parameters such as the mean or standard deviation.
  • Descriptive statistics is a way to organise, represent and describe a collection of data using tables, graphs, and summary measures

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Theoretical statistics: Focuses on the underlying mathematical theory and development of statistical methods, not on data summarization and presentation.

 

Option C. Analytical statistics: This term is less commonly used and does not represent a standard branch of statistics like descriptive or inferential statistics.

 

Option D. Inferential Statistics: Involves using data from a sample to make predictions or inferences about a larger population, including hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.

 

Additional Information

 

Applied Statistics:

 

  • Pure statistics focuses primarily on the numbers, maths, and problems themselves (theoretical)
  • Applied statistics on the other hand, can be thought of as “statistics-in-action” or using statistics with an eye toward real-world problems and what their solutions might be.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Descriptive statistics is dedicated to summarizing and presenting data in an easily understandable way, utilizing tables, graphs, and summary measures.

choices.text: Hydrogen peroxide
Methyl paraben
Bleaching powder

questions.text: Which of the following agents can be used as a disinfectant but not a sanitizer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrogen peroxide

 

Process of bringing down levels of pathogenic organisms on inanimate surfaces to reduce the chances of cross-infection is called as sanitization.

 

Process of destroying all pathogenic organisms is called as disinfection.

 

Process of eliminating all microorganisms in both vegetative and spore state are eliminated from a surface or medium is called as sterilization.

 

Hydrogen peroxide works by producing destructive hydroxyl free radicals that can attack membrane lipids, DNA, and other essential cell components. Catalase, produced by aerobic organisms and facultative anaerobes that possess cytochrome systems, can protect cells from metabolically produced hydrogen peroxide by degrading hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. This defense is overwhelmed by the concentrations used for disinfection.

 

Disinfection or sterilization of cystoscopes, endoscopes, tubing’s, and metal instruments can be done with liquid form of hydrogen peroxide while gaseous form can be used for fogging. It is also used in plasma sterilization.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Penicillin, an antibiotic. It is neither a disinfectant nor a sanitizer.

 

Option C. Methyl paraben is a type of paraben. Parabens are chemicals that are often used as preservatives to give products a longer shelf life.

 

Option D. Household bleaching powder (sodium hypochlorite) is used as a disinfectant in hospitals. Diluted solutions can be used for sanitizing surfaces.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hydrogen peroxide is used as a disinfectant because it effectively destroys a wide range of pathogenic organisms. It is not typically used as a sanitizer, which is a process aimed at reducing, rather than completely eliminating, pathogenic organisms on surfaces.

choices.text: If a and c are correct
If a, b and c are correct
a, b, c, & d are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following is correctly matched?

 

  1. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion
  2. Glucose: facilitated diffusion
  3. Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport
  4. Na: Secondary Active transport
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, b, c, & d are correct

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion: Oxygen is transported by simple passive diffusion based on the concentration gradient. This process does not require any energy input and relies on the natural movement of oxygen molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.

 

Option B. Glucose: facilitated diffusion: Glucose is transported by facilitated diffusion using glucose transporters (GLUTs) and also through Na-dependent transport using sodium-glucose co-transporters (SGLT). GLUTs facilitate glucose transport without energy, while SGLT uses the sodium gradient to transport glucose into cells.

 

Option C. Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport: Calcium is transported by active transport mechanisms, which require energy. These mechanisms include:

  1. Plasma membrane Ca2+ ATPase (PMCA), which pumps calcium out of the cell.
  2. Sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX), which exchanges intracellular calcium for extracellular sodium. Additionally, calcium can be transported via receptor-mediated mechanisms, such as the IP3 receptor, facilitating calcium transport from the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) to the mitochondria.

 

Option D. Na: Secondary Active transport: Sodium often moves down its gradient, but it is also involved in secondary active transport to drive uptake of other substances against their gradients (e.g., glucose in intestines).
The Na⁺/glucose symporter (SGLT) is a classic example.
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each substance (oxygen, glucose, calcium, and sodium) has specific and correct transport mechanisms: oxygen by simple diffusion, glucose by facilitated and Na-dependent transport, calcium by active transport, and sodium by secondary active transport.

 

Reference: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-639

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melanoma

 

Melanoma, on the other hand, is a type of skin cancer primarily associated with UV exposure and is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy. Although people with HIV/AIDS might have a higher risk of developing melanoma due to their immunocompromised state, it is not specifically used to define AIDS.

 

AIDS-defining malignancies are specific types of cancer that are more likely to occur in people with AIDS. These cancers are used in the clinical definition of AIDS because they are directly associated with the immunosuppression caused by the HIV virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kaposi's sarcoma: This cancer is caused by Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and is one of the most common AIDS-defining cancers. It manifests as vascular tumors that can appear on the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Invasive cervical carcinoma: This cancer is linked to the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) and is considered an AIDS-defining condition due to the increased risk in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Particularly the diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) and primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma, are common in AIDS patients due to the compromised immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanoma is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy, unlike Kaposi's sarcoma, invasive cervical carcinoma, and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to OPD with swelling in the upper part of the tibia. X-ray revealed periosteal reaction in upper diaphysis of tibia. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for Synaptophysin and MIC-2. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ewing sarcoma

 

Given clinical scenario, immunohistochemistry showing positive for Synaptophysin and MIC-2 with histopath image showing small round blue cells, points to a diagnosis of Ewing’s sarcoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is an osteoid forming tumor. Patient usually complains of Night pain. But it neither shows small round blue cells on biopsy nor is positive for MIC-2

 

Option C. Metastatic neuroblastoma: Metastatic neuroblastoma also shows Homer wright pseudo rosettes, but it is positive for NSE, PHOX 28.

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma (Giant cell tumor): Osteoclastoma is a benign, locally aggressive bone tumor that is characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells on biopsy. It typically affects the epiphysis of long bones and does not present with small round blue cells or positive staining for MIC-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing sarcoma is a small round blue cell tumor commonly occurring in the diaphysis of long bones in adolescents. It is characterized by positive immunohistochemical staining for Synaptophysin and MIC-2 (CD99).

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 2390-2391

questions.text:
Vaccination against which of the following is recommended in the elderly? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Varicella zoster virus
  2. Rotavirus
  3. Measles
  4. Pneumococcal meningitis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

The vaccination recommendations for the elderly typically include vaccines for Varicella Zoster Virus (to prevent shingles) and Pneumococcal meningitis (to prevent pneumococcal diseases, including meningitis).

 

  • Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV): The recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) is recommended for adults 50 years and older to prevent shingles and its complications.
  • Pneumococcal meningitis: The pneumococcal vaccines (PCV13 and PPSV23) are recommended for adults 65 years and older to protect against pneumococcal diseases, including meningitis and pneumonia.

 

Educational objective

questions.text: The cell wall depicted below is most likely to belong to which of the following organisms?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

The above picture is showing the structure of fungal cell wall most likely of Aspergillus fumigatus.

 

Fungal cell wall components - The fungal cell wall contains a cell membrane with various membrane proteins, a protective layer of chitin (yellow) as well as glucans (mostly beta) and mannoproteins on its surface. Different fungal cell walls contain different glucans. For example, the cell wall of A. fumigatus contains β-1,3- and β-1,4-glucan, and α-1,3-glucan, while C. albicans contains β-1,3- and β-1,6-glucan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis cell wall structure has three major cell wall features, including peptidoglycan, arabinogalactan and mycolic acid.

 

 

Option C. Mycoplasma pneumonia is bound by a trilaminar membrane that contains sterols. Cell wall is absent.

 

 

Option D. Recently, Rhinosporidium seeberi has been considered a fungus, but it was originally thought to be a protozoan parasite. Its morphologic characteristics resemble those of Coccidioides immitis: both organisms have mature stages that consist of large, thick-walled spherical structures containing smaller daughter cells (endospores). In addition, R. seeberi is visualized with fungal stains such as methenamine silver and periodic acid-Schiff, as well as mucicarmine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fungal cell wall of Aspergillus fumigatus contains β-glucans, chitin, and mannoproteins.

questions.text: All of the following coagulation factors increase in pregnancy except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Factor XI

 

Pregnancy induces a hypercoagulable state to prepare the body for the increased risk of bleeding during delivery. This state is characterized by an increase in several coagulation factors, which enhances clot formation.

 

  • Factor II (Prothrombin): Increases during pregnancy. This contributes to a higher risk of clotting.
  • Factor VII: Increases during pregnancy, aiding in the clotting process.
  • Factor VIII: Also increases during pregnancy, enhancing clotting factors and overall coagulation.
  • Factor XI: Does not increase during pregnancy. In fact, Factor XI levels are slightly decreased in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor II: Factor II increases during pregnancy, contributing to the hypercoagulable state.

 

Option B. Factor VII: Factor VII levels increase during pregnancy, supporting the increased coagulation needed.

 

Option C. Factor VIII: Factor VIII increases during pregnancy, which is consistent with the overall increase in clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XI is the coagulation factor that does not increase during pregnancy and may actually decrease slightly.

 

Ref: Page no 508, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text:
A couple already has 3 children and has been trying for another one for the last 1 year. However, the husband is diagnosed with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Which of the following is/are true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Low FSH, low LH
  2. High FSH, low LH
  3. Oligospermia
  4. Low prolactin
  5. Low testosterone
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 5

 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is a condition where there is decreased production of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland, leading to decreased stimulation of the testes and consequent reduced production of sex hormones such as testosterone. This results in:

 

1. Low FSH, low LH: In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, both follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) are low due to inadequate stimulation from the pituitary gland.

 

3. Oligospermia: Reduced levels of FSH and LH lead to decreased stimulation of the testes, which can result in reduced sperm production and oligospermia (low sperm count).

 

5. Low testosterone: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leads to reduced levels of testosterone because the testes are not adequately stimulated by FSH and LH.

 

The following are not true for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism:

 

2. High FSH, low LH: This pattern is more characteristic of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (primary testicular failure) rather than hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

4. Low prolactin: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is typically associated with normal or high levels of prolactin if there is an underlying pituitary issue. Low prolactin is not a characteristic feature of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, both FSH and LH levels are low, testosterone levels are low, and oligospermia is often present.

 

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Denotes latent CMV infection
Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes
Indicates acute CMV infection
IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anti-CMV IgG antibodies? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

 

IgG avidity assays measure the binding strength between IgG antibodies and virus that can help distinguish a primary CMV infection from a past infection. Following primary CMV infection, IgG antibodies have low binding strength (low avidity) then over 2-4 months mature to high binding strength (high avidity). 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Denotes latent CMV infection: While the presence of anti-CMV IgG antibodies indicates a past infection and potential latent infection, it does not specifically denote the current state of latency.

 

Option B. Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes: Anti-CMV IgG antibodies indicate past exposure and potential latent infection but do not confer immunity to all serotypes of CMV.

 

Option C. Indicates acute CMV infection: The presence of anti-CMV IgG antibodies alone does not indicate an acute infection; it suggests past exposure. Acute CMV infection is usually indicated by the presence of anti-CMV IgM antibodies or a significant rise in IgG levels over time.

 

Educational objective

 

An IgG avidity assay is a useful tool to differentiate between a primary CMV infection and a past infection. Low avidity IgG indicates a recent infection, whereas high avidity IgG indicates a past infection.

questions.text: A physician is consulting with a mother who has brought her one-year-old child to a health clinic. The mother mentions that the child received the initial DPT vaccine dose at 6 weeks but has not received any subsequent vaccinations. What would be the most appropriate next step in this child's immunization schedule? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Give second dose of DPT

 

  • If there is delayed immunization in DPT doses, there is no need to repeat the schedule from the start, just continue the schedule. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

choices.text: Hydralazine - heart failure
Atenolol - hemolytic anemia
Aliskiren - hypokalemia

questions.text: Identify the correct match, regarding the drug and its adverse effect?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Verapamil – constipation


The correct match regarding the drug and its adverse effect (read carefully, they have not asked the indication) is verapamil causes constipation.

 

Verapamil is a Non DHP calcium channel blocker. It can cause constipation as its side effect.


Other Options:


Option A. Hydralazine is a vasodilator which can cause drug-induced lupus. It does not cause heart failure as an adverse effect, rather It is used in treatment of heart failure.


Option B. Atenolol is a cardio selective beta blocker. Bradycardia can be seen as a side effect, not hemolytic anemia. Hemolytic anemia is a side effect of methyl dopa.


Option C. Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor. The side effect of aliskiren is hyperkalemia and not hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verapamil, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, is associated with constipation as a common adverse effect. Other drugs and their incorrect matches in this context include hydralazine (which can cause drug-induced lupus), atenolol (which does not cause hemolytic anemia), and aliskiren (which can cause hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia).

questions.text: Banding technique used for dicentric chromosomes:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Explanation:

 

Dicentric chromosome is an abnormal chromosome with two centromeres.

 

 

C banding: stains heterochromatin which are regions of the chromosomes at or near centromere. So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G-banding: G-banding is the most common banding technique and uses Giemsa stain to stain AT-rich regions. It was developed as an alternative to Q-banding due to the cumbersome nature of Q-banding.

 

Option B. NOR-banding: NOR-banding (Nucleolar Organizer Region) is used to stain regions associated with nucleolus formation and is not specifically useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Option D. R-banding: R-banding provides a reverse pattern to G-banding, staining GC-rich regions instead of AT-rich regions. It is not specifically useful for identifying dicentric chromosomes.

 

Note –  Q banding: uses quinacrine dye (first used dye) and stains repetitive AT rich regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C-banding is the preferred technique for identifying dicentric chromosomes as it specifically stains heterochromatin regions at or near the centromere.

 

Reference: Robbins 10th Ed. / page- 262-263, 293

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in damage control surgery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vascular anastomosis

 

Damage control surgery (DCS) is a staged approach that involves minimal intervention to stabilize the patient and perform definitive surgery later. The focus of DCS is on hemorrhage control, resuscitation, and limiting contamination. It includes an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and closure of the abdomen to blunt the physiologic response to prolonged shock and massive hemorrhage. After the initial steps of DCS, definitive surgery involving vascular anastomosis may be performed.

 

Vascular anastomosis is not typically included in damage control surgery.

 

Vascular anastomosis, is generally not performed during the initial phase of damage control surgery. Damage control surgery prioritizes addressing life-threatening injuries and stabilizing the patient. Complex procedures like vascular anastomosis are typically deferred to later, definitive surgery, after the patient's condition has been stabilized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemorrhage control: Hemorrhage control is a critical component of damage control surgery. The primary goal of damage control surgery is to address life-threatening bleeding and stop any ongoing hemorrhage. Surgeons often use various techniques, such as packing wounds or applying temporary closures, to achieve hemorrhage control during the initial phase of damage control surgery.

 

Option B. Resuscitation: Resuscitation is a key aspect of damage control surgery. Patients who require damage control surgery are often in a state of shock due to significant blood loss and trauma. Resuscitation involves stabilizing the patient's condition by providing fluids, blood products, and other supportive measures to restore blood volume and vital organ function. It is usually done in ICU after hemorrhage is stopped.

 

Option C. Decontamination: Decontamination may be necessary in specific situations, such as chemical or biological contamination, gross spillage into peritoneum or dirty wounds.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

vascular anastomosis (option D) is not a standard part of damage control surgery, while the other options (A, B, and C) are relevant components of this surgical approach.

choices.text: MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct

questions.text: Thrombolysis can be considered in all of these conditions, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg

 

Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg: This is a contraindication for thrombolysis. Elevated blood pressure increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications during thrombolysis. Therefore, blood pressure must be controlled to below 185/110 mmHg before initiating thrombolytic therapy.

 

Thrombolysis is a treatment used to dissolve blood clots in certain types of stroke patients. It is most effective when administered within a specific time window from the onset of symptoms and under certain conditions to ensure patient safety and efficacy of the treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct: This indicates that the infarct size is within a range that is generally considered safe for thrombolysis. More extensive infarcts (> 1/3rd of the middle cerebral artery territory) are a contraindication due to the higher risk of hemorrhagic transformation.

 

Option C. Ischemia < 2 hours and D. Onset of symptoms < 4 hours: Both of these options fall within the critical time window for thrombolysis, which is generally considered up to 4.5 hours from symptom onset. Treatment within this time frame can significantly improve outcomes in stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombolysis is contraindicated in patients with blood pressure higher than 185/110 mmHg at the time of treatment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a severe headache is scheduled to undergo a CT scan. During history taking, which of the following will you definitely ask for before the commencement of the scan? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LMP

 

Explanation:

 

The most important information to obtain during a history in a 28-year-old woman of reproductive age who has been referred for a CT scan is the last menstrual period (LMP). Since it is imperative to rule out pregnancy before taking a CT scan, last menstrual period is the most appropriate answer to this question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Use of cochlear implant: While important in MRI to prevent damage to the implant from the magnetic field, it is not typically a concern in CT scans which use X-rays.

 

Option C. History of fall: Although relevant to the medical history, it is not critical specifically before a CT scan unless symptoms suggest complications that a CT scan could exacerbate.

 

Option D. History of hypertension: Important in overall patient assessment but does not directly influence the decision to perform a CT scan as critically as confirming pregnancy status does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inquiring about the Last Menstrual Period (LMP) is essential for any woman of childbearing age before undergoing diagnostic procedures involving radiation, such as a CT scan, to avoid potential harm to an unborn baby.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker is expressed on natural killer cell? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CD 94

 

Natural killer (NK) cells are a type of lymphocyte that play a critical role in the innate immune response, particularly in targeting virally infected cells and tumor cells. They are characterized by the expression of specific surface markers, including CD 16, CD 56, and CD 94. CD 94 is particularly important as it forms part of the receptor complex that NK cells use to recognize and interact with target cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD 68: CD 68 is a marker for macrophages and monocytes

 

Option B. CD 3: CD 3 is a pan T-cell marker

 

Option C. CD 25: CD 25 is a marker for IL2

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 356-357

questions.text:
Which of the following are acid-fast staining organisms? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Nocardia
  2. Mycobacterium leprae
  3. Actinomyces
  4. Cryptosporidium parvum
  5. Isospora belli
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Cystoisospora belli (Options 1, 2, 4, and 5) are acid-fast staining organisms.

 

Acid-fast staining is based on the principle that tubercle bacilli resist decolorization with acids after staining with aniline dyes. Acid fastness is attributed to the variety of fatty acids, alcohols, and lipids in the tubercle bacilli. Acid-fast organisms usually contain mycolic acid, which is acid-fast in the free state. The steps to carry out acid-fast staining as modified by Ziehl and Nelson are:

 

  1. The slide is stained with carbolfuchsin along with the application of heat.
  2. It is then decolorized with 20% sulphuric acid. Later methylene blue is used for counterstaining.
  3. The acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin color, while other organisms take up the counterstain.

 

The genus Nocardia are aerobic organisms and weakly acid-fast positive rods. They stain with carbolfuchsin and retain it when 1-4% sulfuric acid is used.

 

Other Option

 

3. Actinomyces: Actinomyces is not an acid-fast organism. They are gram-positive bacteria that are known for forming filamentous structures similar to fungi but do not retain the acid-fast stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Isospora belli are acid-fast staining organisms.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. It is the most common sporadic renal tumor
  2. Associated with loss of long arm of chromosome 3
  3. Arises from distal convoluted tubule
  4. Cells show intracellular accumulation of glycogen and fat
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4  

 

CLEAR CELL CARCINOMA (Most Common variant)

 

  • Mutation - VHL gene (Occasionally associated with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome). Associated with loss of short arm of chromosome 3.
  • Arise most likely from proximal tubular epithelium, and usually occur as solitary unilateral lesions.
  • Radiographic findings - Hypervascular mass with homogeneous enhancement
  • Gross: Solid mass with a golden-yellow appearance
  • Histopathology - Clear cytoplasm due to washing of accumulated glycogen and lipid droplets. Prominent vasculature and sheets of polygonal cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Associated with loss of short arm of chromosome 3, not long.

 

Statement 3: Arise most likely from proximal tubular epithelium, not distal.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clear cell carcinoma of the kidney is the most common sporadic renal tumor and is characterized by cells with intracellular accumulation of glycogen and fat, as well as an association with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1847-1849

questions.text: In which of the following phenomenon, Cell in cell appearance is seen? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Entosis

 

Cell in cell appearance is seen in Entosis.

 

Entosis is a form of cell death that occurs when one cell inserts itself into the neighboring cell, which results in the ultimate death of the invading cell. This creates a characteristic cell-in-cell (CIC. pattern. It plays a physiological role in the elimination of cells detached from a surface.

 

NOTE: Emperipolesis vs Entosis

 

Emperipolesis is a cellular process in which one cell enters into another cell without being degraded or destroyed. This process occurs in various cell types, including immune cells and cancer cells, and is thought to play a role in cell-to-cell communication and immune surveillance. In emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell after a certain period of time.

 

 

Entosis on the other hand, is a cellular process in which one cell actively engulfs and digests another cell. This process occurs primarily in epithelial cells and is thought to play a role in tissue homeostasis and elimination of damaged or excess cells. In entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell's lysosomes.

 

In summary, the main difference between emperipolesis and entosis is that in emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell, while in entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Necrosis: Necrosis is a form of cell death characterized by uncontrolled cellular breakdown due to injury or disease. It does not involve a cell-in-cell appearance and is marked by cell swelling, membrane rupture, and inflammation.

 

Option B. Apoptosis: Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death involving cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, and the formation of apoptotic bodies, but it does not result in a cell-in-cell appearance. Instead, apoptotic cells are typically engulfed and removed by phagocytes.

 

Option C. Necroptosis: Necroptosis is a regulated form of necrosis or inflammatory cell death that is triggered by certain death receptors. Like necrosis, it does not involve a cell-in-cell appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cell-in-cell appearance is characteristic of entosis, where one cell engulfs and digests another, distinguishing it from other forms of cell death.

choices.text: Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign
Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer
Median age of survival is 6 months in all cases

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the hospital with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. She was diagnosed with cholecystitis and cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. The post-operative biopsy reports came back positive for gallbladder carcinoma. What is true about gallbladder carcinoma? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer

 

This statement is correct. The clinical presentation of gallstones (cholelithiasis) and gallbladder cancer (carcinoma) can sometimes be distinguished. Gallstones commonly cause symptoms such as biliary colic (episodic, severe right upper quadrant pain) and may lead to acute cholecystitis, which includes symptoms like pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. In contrast, gallbladder carcinoma may present with more persistent or progressive symptoms, including unexplained weight loss and, in some cases, a palpable abdominal mass. The two conditions can have overlapping symptoms, but their clinical courses can be distinguished based on the duration and progression of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign: This statement is not true. A palpable abdominal lump is not typically the earliest sign of gallbladder carcinoma. Gallbladder carcinoma often presents with nonspecific symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. As the cancer progresses, it may cause other symptoms, but a palpable lump is usually a late finding.

 

Option B. Earliest sign is jaundice: This statement is also not true for most cases of gallbladder carcinoma. Jaundice is more commonly associated with cancers of the bile ducts (cholangiocarcinoma) or pancreatic cancer when the tumor obstructs the bile ducts. While gallbladder carcinoma can cause jaundice if it obstructs the common bile duct, it is not typically the earliest sign of the disease.

 

Option D. Median age of survival is 6 months: This statement is not accurate for all cases of gallbladder carcinoma. The survival rate for gallbladder carcinoma can vary widely depending on factors such as the stage at diagnosis and the extent of surgical resection. While some cases have a poor prognosis with a short median survival, others may have a better outcome if diagnosed at an earlier stage and treated appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Option C is correct because gallstones and gallbladder carcinoma often have distinct clinical presentations, allowing them to be distinguished from each other.

choices.text: Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction
A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent
FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

questions.text: A patient presents to you with left-sided flank pain. A CT scan was done which is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

 

Above CT image shows left renal hydatid cyst. In this case, FNAC or biopsy should not be done before nephrectomy as puncture of the cyst while obtaining cystic fluid may cause escape of hydatid fluid and consequent anaphylaxis. Therefore, fluid aspirated from surgically removed cyst should only be examined.

 

Echinococcus causes hydatid cyst in man. It is segmented and smaller than other cestodes.

 

Most of the times infection is asymptomatic and accidentally discovered.

 

Clinical disease develops only when the hydatid cyst has grown big enough to cause obstructive symptoms. Disease results mainly from pressure effects caused by the enlarging cysts.

 

In about half the cases, the primary hydatid cyst occurs in liver, mostly in the right lobe. Hepatomegaly, pain and obstructive jaundice are the usual manifestations.

 

The next common site is the lung (25%) (most common being the lower lobe of the right lung). Cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, pneumothorax and dyspnea constitute the clinical picture.

 

In the kidney (2%), hydatid cyst causes pain and hematuria.

 

Apart from pressure effects, another pathogenic mechanism in hydatid disease is hypersensitivity to the echinococcal antigen. The host is sensitized to the antigen by minute amounts of hydatid fluid seeping through the capsule. Hypersensitivity may cause urticaria. But if a hydatid cyst ruptures spontaneously or during surgical interference/FNAC, massive release of hydatid fluid may cause severe, even fatal anaphylaxis.

 

CT imaging is diagnostic to visualize daughter cysts within large cysts

 

Treatment

 

Traditionally surgical removal was considered as the best mode of treatment of cysts.

 

Currently, ultrasound staging is recommended and management depends on the stage.

 

In early stages, the treatment of choice is puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration (PAIR).

 

Puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration, considered as a controversial procedure earlier, is now widely used in early stages of the disease. The basic steps involved in PAlR include:

 

  • Ultrasound or CT-guided puncture of the cyst.
  • Aspiration of cyst fluid.
  • Infusion of sporicidal agent (usually 95% ethanol; alternatively, hypertonic saline)
  • Reaspiration of the fluid after 5 minutes.
  • Great care is taken to avoid spillage and cavities are sterilized with 0.5% silver nitrate or 2.7% sodium chloride for prophylaxis of secondary peritoneal echinococcosis due to inadvertent spillage of fluid du ring PAIR.

 

Albendazole (15 mg/ kg in row divided doses) is initiated 4 days before the procedure and continued for 4 weeks afterwards.

 

Surgery: It is the treatment of choice for complicated E. granulosus cysts like those communicating with the biliary tract and in those cysts where PAIR is not possible.

 

Renal involvement requires surgical treatment, either simple excision of the cyst or partial/total nephrectomy if extensive disease.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Albendazole can be started preoperatively: This is correct. Albendazole (15 mg/kg in two divided doses) is initiated 4 days before any surgical or puncture procedure and continued for 4 weeks afterwards to reduce the risk of spillage and subsequent anaphylactic reaction.

 

Option B. Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction: This is correct. The contents of a hydatid cyst contain highly antigenic material, and rupture or spillage of this material can cause a severe anaphylactic reaction.

 

Option C. A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent: This is correct. Echinococcus granulosus, a segmented tapeworm found in dogs, is the causative agent of hydatid disease.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hydatid disease, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by cyst formation in organs such as the liver, lungs, and kidneys. FNAC or biopsy should not be done in cases of suspected hydatid cysts due to the risk of anaphylaxis and dissemination of the infection.

questions.text: Which of the following local  anaesthetic causes hypertension?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine

 

Cocaine: An ester local anesthetic that is also a powerful central nervous system stimulant. One of the well-known cardiovascular effects of cocaine is hypertension, due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine: is an amide local anesthetic that is used to produce numbness during procedures and for treating various types of pain. It can cause side effects such as dizziness and low blood pressure but is not known for causing hypertension.

 

Option C. Bupivacaine: An amide local anesthetic known for its potent and long-lasting numbing effect. It can cause cardiovascular complications, but like lignocaine, it is more associated with cardiac toxicity rather than hypertension.

 

Option D. Prilocaine: Another amide local anesthetic, similar to lignocaine, and not commonly associated with causing hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cocaine is the local anesthetic known to cause hypertension due to its vasoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: The absence of loud S1 in mitral stenosis would indicate all of the following, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild mitral stenosis

 

The first heart sound (S1) is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of systole. In mitral stenosis, the loudness of S1 can vary depending on several factors. A loud S1 is typically associated with the early stages of mitral stenosis when the valve leaflets are still relatively mobile. However, in certain conditions, S1 can become softer.

 

In mild mitral stenosis without significant calcification usually results in a loud S1. This is because the mitral valve leaflets are still relatively mobile and can close forcefully.
