  • Therefore, stating nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation is false as it is more common in posterior dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vascular injury more common in anterior hip dislocation. This statement is correct. This is so because the femoral vessels are in close proximity to the hip joint anteriorly, so there are more chances of vascular injury to occur from anterior hip dislocation. Major vascular injuries are rare in both anterior and posterior dislocations. 

 

Option C. Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior. This statement is correct. The incidence of posterior dislocation of hip is around 90%. This is because of the greater strength of anterior ligaments than the posterior ones. 

 

Option D. In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation. This statement is true. The position of the limb when a patient presents with posterior hip dislocation is of Flexion, Adduction and Internal Rotation i.e., FADIR while in anterior dislocation, it is FABER i.e., Flexion, Abduction and External Rotation. 

 

 

FADIR in posterior hip dislocation

 

Educational Objective:

 

In anterior dislocation of hip, vascular injuries are more common whereas in posterior dislocation, nerve injury (particularly sciatic nerve) is more common.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of central cyanosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypothermia

 

Central cyanosis occurs when there is a significant amount of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood, typically due to issues with oxygenation or hemoglobin abnormalities.

 

In contrast, hypothermia leads to peripheral cyanosis, not central cyanosis. In hypothermia, the blood flow is sluggish due to vasoconstriction, particularly in the extremities, which results in a bluish discoloration of the skin. However, the central organs typically remain oxygenated.

 

Other Options:

 

Central cyanosis can be caused by several factors:

 

Option A. Methemoglobinemia: This condition involves the presence of methemoglobin in the blood, which does not carry oxygen effectively, leading to central cyanosis.

 

Option B. Pulmonary Arteriovenous Fistula: This abnormal connection between an artery and a vein in the lungs allows blood to bypass the alveoli, leading to poorly oxygenated blood entering the systemic circulation, causing central cyanosis.

 

Option C. High Altitude: At high altitudes, the reduced atmospheric pressure leads to lower oxygen availability, causing hypoxemia and central cyanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia causes only peripheral cyanosis due to sluggish blood flow, not central cyanosis

questions.text: Arrange the following anaethesia agents on the basis of their potency.(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methoxyflurane>Halothane>Isoflurane>Nitrous oxide

 

Explanation:

 

Potency of Anesthetic Agents:

  • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is measured by their Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC). The MAC value is inversely proportional to the potency; lower MAC values indicate higher potency.

 

MAC Values:

  • Methoxyflurane: 0.16
  • Halothane: 0.75
  • Isoflurane: 1.4
  • Nitrous oxide: 104

 

Order of Potency (from most potent to least potent):

  • Methoxyflurane: With the lowest MAC of 0.16, it is the most potent agent.
  • Halothane: With a MAC of 0.75, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane but more potent than Isoflurane and Nitrous oxide.
  • Isoflurane: With a MAC of 1.4, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane and Halothane but more potent than Nitrous oxide.
  • Nitrous oxide: With the highest MAC of 104, it is the least potent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane > Methoxyflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide has the highest MAC and is the least potent, while Methoxyflurane is the most potent.

 

Option C. Methoxyflurane > Isoflurane > Halothane > Nitrous oxide: Incorrect, as Halothane is more potent than Isoflurane.

 

Option D. Methoxyflurane > Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide is the least potent and should be at the end of the sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is inversely proportional to their MAC values. Methoxyflurane, with the lowest MAC, is the most potent, while Nitrous oxide, with the highest MAC, is the least potent. The correct order of potency is Methoxyflurane > Halothane > Isoflurane > Nitrous oxide.

choices.text: Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy
Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction
High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe
Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about lupus nephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder involving the multisystem. It affects young women of childbearing age. The renal involvement of the disease can manifest in the form of active lupus nephritis or flare-ups during pregnancy.
  • It can lead to preterm births, preeclampsia, and pregnancy loss while the infant can suffer from neonatal lupus and heart block.
  • Management includes
  • Preconceptionally counseling: Conception during a period of quiescence for at least 6 months determines a successful outcome. Stable remission of renal disease for at least 6 months before conception is recommended.
  • Corticosteroids are useful during episodes of lupus flare and can be used safely in pregnancy.
  • Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine can be continued during pregnancy. It may be used in case of severe SLE
  • Hydroxychloroquine is found to be the best for maintenance and is safe in pregnancy. It can prevent the need for prolonged corticosteroid therapy.
  • Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and hence they are not safe during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy: Correct. Medications like azathioprine can be continued under medical guidance, while others are used cautiously.

 

Option B. Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction: Correct. Quiescence of the disease and stable renal function are crucial for a successful pregnancy outcome.

 

Option C. High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe: Correct. High doses of corticosteroids can be used during a lupus flare, but must be carefully monitored.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are not safe during pregnancy for managing lupus nephritis; corticosteroids and azathioprine are safer options.

 

Ref: Page 2895, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with schizophrenia was started on risperidone. After taking the medication last night, the patient rushes to OPD today with complaints of upwards rolling of his eyes. What is the management of the condition? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promethazine

 

The patient is experiencing oculogyric crisis, which is an acute dystonic reaction caused by antipsychotic medications. This is an extrapyramidal side effect that involves sustained, involuntary upward deviation of the eyes.

 

This is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties. It's commonly used as the first-line treatment for acute dystonic reactions, including oculogyric crisis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lorazepam: Useful for generalized dystonia or akathisia but not the first line for acute oculogyric crisis.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Another antipsychotic, it wouldn't directly treat the acute dystonic reaction.

 

Option D. Stop antipsychotic: While it might be necessary to review and adjust the antipsychotic regimen if a patient is having side effects, simply stopping the antipsychotic won't provide immediate relief from an acute dystonic reaction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect, is characterized by spasm of muscles in any part of the body, e.g., oculogyric crisis, torticollis. It is seen in about 10% of patients on antipsychotics. Risk factors include young males, those who are antipsychotic naive and high potency antipsychotics. It usually occurs within hours of starting antipsychotic medication. They can be distressing but are reversible. Anticholinergic agents like promethazine (IM or IV) are first-line treatments for these reactions.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 110-111

choices.text: Muscle fasciculations

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency room after poisoning with an unknown substance. Muscarinic poisoning was suspected and he was treated for the same. What is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bradycardia
 

The types of Muscarinic receptors and their actions are as follows:

 

  • M1 – They increase the acid secretion in the stomach
  • M2 – They are present in the heart and lead to a decrease in heart rate (Bradycardia) and cause slowing of conduction in the AV node.
  • M3 – They are present in the respiratory tract and cause bronchoconstriction. They are also present in the urinary bladder, where they help in urination by bringing about contraction of the bladder. In the glands, these receptors help in secretion. In the eyes it leads to miosis.

 

Bradycardia is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning in this case. Muscarinic poisoning occurs due to the consumption of poisonous mushroom-like Inocybe. Muscarinic symptoms appear within an hour of eating the mushroom. These symptoms (along with nicotinic symptoms) can also be seen in organophosphate poisoning. Atropine is used for the management of muscarinic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mydriasis: This refers to pupil dilation, which is typically associated with sympathetic stimulation or anticholinergic effects, not muscarinic poisoning.

 

Option B. Diuresis: This refers to increased urine production, which is not a direct effect of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic activation actually increases bladder contraction, promoting urination.

 

Option C. Muscle fasciculations: These are more associated with nicotinic receptor activation, not muscarinic receptor activation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bradycardia is a key presenting feature that can lead to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic receptors, particularly M2 receptors in the heart, mediate a decrease in heart rate. Atropine is used to manage muscarinic poisoning by blocking acetylcholine's action on these receptors.

questions.text: Identify the pathognomonic structure in the slide given below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sclerotic body

 

The histopathological picture shows brown coloured thick walled round cells that have transverse septations within them. These are called as Sclerotic bodies, also known as muriform cells or Medlar bodies, or copper penny appearance a found in tissue biopsies of patients with chromoblastomycosis. These bodies are a key diagnostic feature of this fungal infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Budding yeast: This is a general term for yeast cells reproducing through budding. It is not pathognomonic for a specific disease without further context.

 

Option C. Negri bodies are intracytoplasmic, round purplish structures with basophilic inner granules. They are pathognomic of rabies.

 

 

Option D. Asteroid bodies are oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation. They are antigen-antibody complexes deposits. Seen in sporotricosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Few Important Pathognomonic structures associated with disease:

questions.text: The given diagram shows the steps in bacterial cell wall formation. Identify the site of action of beta-lactam antibiotics. (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Beta lactams act on step 4 in the given image.

 

The beta lactams inhibit the formation of bacterial cell wall by inhibiting the Transpeptidase enzyme which is required for the cross linking of the peptidoglycan chains; therefore, they lead to a reduction in the strength of the bacterial cell wall which ultimately causes it to burst, leading to the death of the bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Fosfomycin inhibits step 1 in the image. It inhibits the cytoplasmic enzyme enol pyruvate transferase that catalyses the initial step in the bacterial cell wall synthesis. It is used for the treatment of urinary tract infections.

 

Option B. 2: Bacitracin inhibits step 2 in the image. It is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that interferes with dephosphorylation of the BP transporter which transfers peptidoglycan subunits to the growing cell wall.

 

Option C. 3: Vancomycin inhibits step 3 in the image. It binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-lactam antibiotics act at step 4 in the bacterial cell wall synthesis process by inhibiting transpeptidase enzymes, which are essential for cross-linking peptidoglycan chains, thereby weakening the bacterial cell wall and causing cell lysis.

choices.text: N - hydroxy cyclophosphamide
4 - hydroxy cyclophosphamide
4 - acetyl cyclophosphamide
N - acetyl cyclophosphamide

questions.text: The active metabolite of cyclophosphamide is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4 - hydroxy cyclophosphamide

 

  • Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating chemotherapeutic agent whose active metabolite is 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide.
  • Side Effects:
    • Hemorrhagic Cystitis: One of the most notable side effects of cyclophosphamide is hemorrhagic cystitis. This is due to the accumulation of the metabolite acrolein in the bladder. To prevent this, mesna (a uroprotective agent) is administered alongside cyclophosphamide, and patients are advised to maintain adequate hydration.
    • Pulmonary Fibrosis: Another significant side effect is pulmonary fibrosis, which can affect lung function.
    • Bone Marrow Suppression: Like many chemotherapeutic agents, cyclophosphamide can also cause bone marrow suppression, leading to leukopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclophosphamide's therapeutic effects are primarily due to its active metabolite, 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide. It is important to manage the side effects of cyclophosphamide, particularly hemorrhagic cystitis, through the use of mesna and adequate hydration. Pulmonary fibrosis and bone marrow suppression are other significant side effects to be monitored during treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Mollicutes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureaplasma urealyticum

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall.

 

They vary in form, although most have sterols that make the cell membrane somewhat more rigid.

 

Many are able to move about through gliding, but members of the genus Spiroplasma are helical and move by twisting.

 

The best-known genus in the Mollicutes is Mycoplasma. Colonies show the typical “fried-egg” appearance.

 

Mollicutes are parasites of various animals and plants, living on or in the host’s cells. Many cause diseases in humans, attaching to cells in the respiratory or urogenital tracts, particularly species of Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma. Phytoplasma and Spiroplasma are plant pathogens associated with insect vectors.

 

Ureaplasma urealyticum has the ability to hydrolyse urea. It causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Orientia tsutsugamushi: This bacterium belongs to the family Rickettsiaceae and is the causative agent of scrub typhus, which is transmitted by mites.

 

Option C. Chlamydophila pneumonia: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydophila, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydia, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes various infections, including trachoma and sexually transmitted infections.

 

Educational Objective

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The most well-known genera in this class are Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma, with Ureaplasma urealyticum being a notable example that causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female patient presents with complaint of sudden diminishing vision. On examination, relative afferent pupillary defect is noted in the right eye and the left eye is normal. Which of the following investigations would you do next? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. MRI brain and orbit
  2. Myelin oligodendrocyte oligoprotein (MOG) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO) antibodies
  3. Blood sugar
  4. Thyroid profile
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

  • The presented clinical features suggest optic neuritis, which is characterized by sudden, progressive, and profound visual loss along with relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
  • The recommended investigations for optic neuritis include MRI brain and orbit, screening for circulating MOG and NMO antibodies, and checking blood sugar levels.
  • Brain MRI is suggested in every patient after the first attack of optic neuritis, as there is a high probability of developing multiple sclerosis.
  • Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is a severe type of optic neuritis that can occur bilaterally and is associated with myelitis. The presence of MOG and MO antibodies can diagnose the condition.
  • Reason for checking blood glucose level-
    • If it turns out to be optic neuritis, blood glucose levels should be measured as steroids are mainstay treatment modality
  • Marcus Gunn pupil, which indicates RAPD, is a characteristic sign of optic neuritis. It is elicited by the swinging flashlight test, where the eyes' response to light is observed by swinging the flashlight multiple times.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Thyroid profile: This is generally not directly relevant to acute visual changes associated with optic neuritis unless there is a suspicion of thyroid eye disease, which typically presents with other distinctive signs such as exophthalmos, eyelid retraction, and ophthalmoplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of sudden visual loss with RAPD, it is crucial to perform a thorough diagnostic evaluation to determine the underlying cause. MRI of the brain and orbits, along with specific antibody tests for MOG and NMO, provide critical information for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of optic neuritis and related conditions. Monitoring blood sugar levels is also essential, especially in the context of potential steroid therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior gluteal artery

 

  • Origin: The inferior gluteal artery is typically a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, usually below the piriformis muscle. It supplies the gluteal muscles (mainly gluteus maximus), and also gives off branches that participate in anastomoses around the hip joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iliolumbar Artery

 

  • Origin: This arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It ascends posteriorly to supply the iliacus muscle, the iliac bone, and the lumbosacral region. Its branches also participate in anastomoses with the lumbar arteries.

 

Option B. Lateral Sacral Artery

 

  • Origin: This too arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: Generally, there are two lateral sacral arteries (superior and inferior) that descend to supply the sacrum and coccyx. They anastomose with the median sacral artery and with each other. Some branches of the lateral sacral arteries also supply the meninges of the sacral part of the spinal cord.

 

Option D. Superior Gluteal Artery

 

  • Origin: This artery arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.
  • Course & Supply: It leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, usually above the piriformis muscle. It supplies the gluteal muscles and also contributes to the anastomotic network around the hip joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

 

  1. Vaginal artery (in females)
  2. Uterine artery (in females)
  3. Inferior vesical artery (in males) or vaginal artery (in females): supplies the urinary bladder and reproductive organs.
  4. Middle rectal artery: supplies the rectum and anal canal.
  5. Internal pudendal artery: supplies the perineum, external genitalia, and the lower anal canal.
  6. Obturator artery: supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh, external genitalia, and the hip joint.
  7. Inferior gluteal artery: supplies the muscles of the gluteal region.
  8. Superior vesical artery: supplies the urinary bladder and the vas deferens.

choices.text: Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost
Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth
PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery
Causes include retained placenta and atony

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH)? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost

 

The false statement regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH) is option A. The standard practice for managing PPH is to start intravenous isotonic crystalloids rather than colloids. Colloids are generally reserved for specific situations and are not the initial choice for fluid resuscitation in PPH. The correct approach involves using crystalloids to replace lost blood volume. The recommendation is not to administer colloids at a volume four times the amount of blood lost.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth: This statement is true. Primary or early postpartum hemorrhage refers to blood loss occurring within the first 24 hours after delivery.

 

Option C. PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery: This statement is true. Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as a blood loss greater than 500 ml following a vaginal delivery and more than 1000 ml following a cesarean section.

 

Option D. Causes include retained placenta and atony: This statement is true. Common causes of postpartum hemorrhage include uterine atony (failure of the uterus to contract) and retained placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management of post-partum hemorrhage should involve intravenous isotonic crystalloids, not colloids.

 

Ref: Page 1894, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that arises from the marked part? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Abducens nerve

 

The image shows the abducens nerve.

 

Origin: The abducens nerve originates in the pons. Its fibers arise from the abducens nucleus, which is located in the dorsal pons near the floor of the fourth ventricle.

 

Exit Point: It emerges from the ventral surface of the brainstem at the junction between the pons and the medulla, in the groove between the pons and the pyramid of the medulla.

 

Function: It innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve (III)

 

  • Origin: The oculomotor nerve originates in the anterior aspect of the midbrain. Specifically, its fibers arise from the oculomotor nucleus, which is located in the superior colliculus of the midbrain.
  • Exit Point: After emerging from the midbrain, it exits the brainstem at the level of the interpeduncular fossa (the space between the cerebral peduncles).
  • Function: It innervates most of the muscles controlling eye movements. It also contains parasympathetic fibers that are involved in pupil constriction and the lens's accommodation.

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal Nerve (IX)

 

  • Origin: The glossopharyngeal nerve arises from the medulla oblongata, specifically from the postolivary sulcus, which lies lateral to the olive.
  • Exit Point: It exits the brainstem in a groove between the olive and the inferior cerebellar peduncle, alongside the vagus (X) and accessory (XI) nerves.
  • Function: It has several roles, including taste from the posterior third of the tongue, sensation from the upper pharynx, and innervation of the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Option D. Facial Nerve (VII)

 

  • Origin: The facial nerve arises from the pons. Specifically, its fibers come from the facial nerve nucleus.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle, between the pons and the medulla. It exits lateral to the abducens nerve and medial to the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).
  • Function: The facial nerve controls the muscles of facial expression. It also has taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and carries parasympathetic fibers to salivary and lacrimal glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The abducens nerve, also known as cranial nerve VI, arises from the abducens nucleus in the pontomedullary junction, which is located in the lower part of the pons and upper part of the medulla oblongata in the brainstem. It exits the brainstem at the junction of the pons and medulla oblongata and travels through the cavernous sinus to innervate the lateral rectus muscle of the eye. Its main function is to control eye movement and allow for horizontal gaze.

choices.text: Growth of 103 coliform in suprapubic sample
Growth of 105 coliform in voided urine sample
Frequency with dysuria with positive nitrite and leucoesterase dipstick test

questions.text: Urinary tract infection in a pregnant lady in her 2nd trimester is best defined as: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growth of 105 coliform in voided urine sample

 

Explanation:

 

A urinary tract infection (UTI) in a pregnant woman is best defined by the growth of 10^5 coliforms per milliliter in a voided urine sample. This threshold is used to differentiate significant bacterial growth from contamination or a non-infectious presence of bacteria.

 

In pregnancy, the standard diagnostic method for UTI is a urine culture. A growth of 10^5 or more coliforms per milliliter in a properly collected voided urine sample is considered diagnostic for UTI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Growth of 103 coliform in suprapubic sample: Growth of 10^3 coliforms in a suprapubic sample is not a standard criterion for diagnosing UTI. Typically, suprapubic aspiration is used for more precise diagnoses, and lower thresholds may be acceptable due to reduced contamination risk compared to voided samples. However, for voided samples, the threshold is higher.

 

Option C. Frequency with dysuria with >3 WBC/HPF: Frequency with dysuria and >3 WBC/HPF indicates inflammation and possible infection but does not define a UTI by itself. The presence of WBCs in urine is a sign of inflammation or infection but is not specific for diagnosis.

 

Option D. Frequency with dysuria with positive nitrite and leucoesterase dipstick test: Frequency with dysuria and positive nitrite and leucocyte esterase dipstick tests suggest a UTI but are not definitive. These tests are helpful as preliminary screening tools but are not as definitive as a quantitative urine culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A urinary tract infection in a pregnant lady in her 2nd trimester is best defined as the growth of 10^5 coliforms in a voided urine sample.

 

Ref: Page no 348, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 6th edition

questions.text: A young boy with a history of multiple blood transfusions presents with bone pain for the past 6 months. A peripheral smear showed sickle-shaped RBCs. Which of the following drugs are not used in the treatment of his condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bebtelovimab

 

  • The given clinical features are suggestive of Sickle cell anemia. Voxelotor, hydroxyurea and L-glutamine are used for treatment of sickle cell anemia whereas Bebtelovimab is not used in in this condition.
  • Bebtelovimab is a new monoclonal antibody used for the treatment of COVID-19. It works by binding to the spike protein of the COVID-19 virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Voxelotor: Is an inhibitor of hemoglobin S polymerase and stabilizer of sickle cell hemoglobin (HbS) that is used in the therapy of sickle cell disease.

 

Option C. Hydroxyurea: Improves fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and is the primary drug for controlling HbS in sickle cell disease. Thus, improving the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

 

Option D. L-glutamine: Is a naturally occurring amino acid with antioxidant properties. It increases the availability of reduced glutathione which may lessen oxidative damage in sickle red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bebtelovimab is not used in the treatment of sickle cell anemia; it is a monoclonal antibody used for COVID-19 treatment. In contrast, Voxelotor, Hydroxyurea, and L-glutamine are used in managing sickle cell anemia by improving hemoglobin function and reducing oxidative stress in red blood cells.

choices.text: Droplet digital PCR

questions.text: Best method for detection of mutations with low allele frequency is? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Droplet digital PCR

 

Option A. Droplet digital PCR : Digital Droplet PCR (ddPCR) is known as the third generation of quantitative PCR and is the Best method for detection of mutation with low allele frequency.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH): FISH is a cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes to bind to specific DNA sequences. While it is valuable for detecting chromosomal abnormalities, it may not be as sensitive as ddPCR for detecting mutations at low allele frequencies.

 

Option C. Nested PCR: Nested PCR involves two rounds of PCR amplification, with the second round using primers nested within the product of the first round. While it can increase sensitivity, it may not be as quantitative or precise as ddPCR.

 

Option D. Sanger Sequencing: Sanger sequencing is a traditional DNA sequencing method. While it is highly accurate, it may not be as sensitive as ddPCR for detecting low-frequency mutations. It is more suitable for identifying mutations present at higher allele frequencies.

 

Educational objective:

 

Droplet Digital PCR (ddPCR)

 

Principle: Droplet digital PCR is a highly sensitive and quantitative method for detecting and quantifying nucleic acids. It partitions the PCR reaction into thousands of droplets, and each droplet serves as an individual reaction chamber.

 

Advantages: It allows for absolute quantification of DNA with high precision and sensitivity. It is particularly effective in detecting mutations present at low allele frequencies.

 

Application: ddPCR is widely used for detecting rare mutations, monitoring minimal residual disease, and assessing low-abundance targets in various samples.

questions.text: A clinician is attending to several patients with different conditions in a hospital setting. Which of the following diseases necessitates placing the patient in a separate isolation room due to its airborne transmission risk? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Measles is a highly contagious viral disease that spreads primarily through the air via respiratory droplets from coughs or sneezes of infected individuals. Its high transmissibility requires that patients be isolated in airborne infection isolation rooms to prevent the spread of the virus to others, particularly the unvaccinated or immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal, rabies does not require airborne isolation as it is not spread through the air.

 

Option C. Nipah: While Nipah virus can be transmitted from person to person, it is primarily spread through direct contact with infected bats, pigs, or other Nipah-infected individuals' body fluids. Airborne transmission is not the primary mode.

 

Option D. Aseptic meningitis: Generally caused by viral infections and not considered highly contagious through the air. Transmission is typically through direct contact with an infected person's respiratory secretions or feces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles necessitates isolation in an airborne infection isolation room due to its high potential for airborne transmission, making it critical to prevent its spread in healthcare settings.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with left-sided hemiparesis. Damage to which part of the internal capsule leads to this presentation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior limb

 

The internal capsule is a white matter structure in the brain that contains many important tracts, including those for motor and sensory functions. Damage to specific parts of the internal capsule can result in different clinical presentations based on the fibers that are affected.

 

Posterior limb is the part of the internal capsule that carries corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, which are responsible for motor and sensory functions. Damage to the posterior limb can result in contralateral hemiparesis (weakness on the opposite side of the body). Therefore, a lesion in the posterior limb of the right internal capsule would lead to left-sided hemiparesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: This part of the internal capsule contains optic radiations, which are involved in visual processing. Damage here would lead to visual deficits rather than motor or sensory deficits.

 

Option B. Sublentiform: This part carries auditory radiations and is involved in hearing. Damage to this part would result in auditory deficits, not motor weakness.

 

Option C. Anterior limb: This part of the internal capsule contains frontopontine fibers and thalamocortical radiations, which are involved in cognitive and executive functions. Damage here might affect cognition but not typically result in hemiparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule can lead to contralateral hemiparesis due to the involvement of motor and sensory pathways.

choices.text: In children, equally among males and females
In adults, equally among males and females
In adults, occurs more in males than in females
In children, occurs more in females than in males

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with sudden-onset blindness for the past 4 hours. However, on history taking, it is noted that she is not concerned about it. However, she is concerned that her mother passed away recently and that she should have spent more time with her. Physical examination findings are normal. Which of the following is true about the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In children, occurs more in females than in males

 

The patient is likely experiencing a conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder. It's characterized by neurological symptoms (such as blindness, paralysis, or seizures) that can't be explained by medical evaluation and are presumably linked to psychological factors. The indifference towards the symptom (e.g., not being concerned about sudden blindness) is termed "la belle indifférence," although this feature is not always present.

 

In pediatric populations, females are more commonly affected than males.

 

Other Others:

 

Option A. In children, equally among males and females: Incorrect. In children, the condition is more common in females.

 

Option B. In adults, equally among males and females: Incorrect. In adults, conversion disorder is more common in females than in males.

 

Option C. In adults, occurs more in males than in females: Incorrect. The disorder is more common in females than in males in both adults and children.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Conversion disorder, also known as dissociative neurological symptom disorder, is characterized by neurological symptoms that can't be explained by a medical condition and are believed to arise in response to psychological stressors. The symptoms do not conform with anatomical and physiological principles. The condition is more common in females in both pediatric and adult populations.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 451-467.

questions.text: All of the following are the part of the innate immunity except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B lymphocytes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha defensins: These are antimicrobial peptides that are part of the innate immune system. They are produced by neutrophils and epithelial cells and help to protect against a wide range of pathogens.

 

Option C. Gamma Delta T lymphocytes: These are a subset of T cells that participate in both the innate and adaptive immune responses. They are considered part of the innate immune system due to their ability to respond quickly and non-specifically to a wide range of pathogens.

 

Option D. Lectin pathway: The lectin pathway is one of the pathways that activate the complement system, a key component of innate immunity. It is initiated by the binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to pathogen surfaces.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Uracil was found in genetic code. Which vitamin deficiency leads to this condition:(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Folate

 

  • Folate deficiency is the correct answer. Folate (also known as vitamin B9) plays a crucial role in DNA synthesis and repair. When there is a deficiency in folate, it can lead to the misincorporation of Uracil into DNA, causing DNA instability and other genetic abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12: A deficiency in vitamin B12 is not directly associated with the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B12 deficiency primarily affects red blood cell production and neurological functions.

 

Option B. B6: A deficiency in vitamin B6 is also not directly related to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to various neurological symptoms but does not cause Uracil incorporation into DNA.

 

Option D. Vit E: Vitamin E deficiency does not lead to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin E is primarily known for its antioxidant properties and its role in maintaining cell membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genetic code is related to DNA, but DNA do not contain Uracil. In pyrimidine synthesis, UMP is the first pyrimidine nucleotide to be synthesized and other two pyrimidines thymine and Cytosine are synthesized from it. Uracil to cytosine conversion requires amino group addition provided by glutamine. Uracil is converted to thymine by enzyme thymidylate synthase by methylation where methyl group is donated by methyl-THF. So, a deficiency Folate will result in thymine deficiency and may lead to uracil appearing in the DNA in place of thymine.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 333

questions.text: Match the following transporters with the molecule they carry. (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1c, 2d, 3a, 4b

 

Hemopexin transports free heme. Haptoglobin binds to and transports hemoglobin. Pre-albumin, also known as transthyretin, transports thyroxin and retinol binding protein. Albumin transports various hydrophobic substances, including free fatty acids, bilirubin, steroid hormones, and many drugs. The correct match is:

 

  1. Hemopexin - c. Heme
    Hemopexin specifically binds and transports free heme to prevent its oxidative damage.
  2. Haptoglobin - d. Hemoglobin
    Haptoglobin binds to free hemoglobin released from erythrocytes, preventing loss of iron and kidney damage.
  3. Pre-albumin - a. Thyroxin
    Pre-albumin (transthyretin) transports thyroxin (T4) and retinol-binding protein.
  4. Albumin - b. Free fatty acid
    Albumin transports a wide range of substances, including free fatty acids, bilirubin, steroid hormones, and various drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct match can be given as:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 630-631

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong regarding primary and secondary immune response? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given statement that antibody affinity is higher in the primary immune response and lower in the secondary immune response is incorrect. The correct comparison should be:

 

  • Primary Immune Response: This occurs as a result of the first contact with an antigen. It typically involves a longer lag period (4-10 days) before antibodies are produced. The initial antibodies produced are primarily IgM, with lower affinity for the antigen.
  • Secondary Immune Response: This occurs as a result of subsequent exposures to the same antigen. It involves a shorter lag period (1-3 days) due to the presence of memory cells. The antibodies produced are primarily IgG, which have higher affinity for the antigen compared to those produced in the primary response. The secondary response is more rapid and robust, producing higher levels of antibodies that persist for a longer period.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Lag period: Correctly identified; the primary immune response has a longer lag period (4-10 days), while the secondary immune response has a shorter lag period (1-3 days).

 

Option B. Antibody response: Correctly identified; the secondary immune response is more potent than the primary immune response.

 

Option C. Isotype generated: Correctly identified; the primary response mainly produces IgM, while the secondary response mainly produces IgG.

 

Educational objective

questions.text: Identify the plant given in the image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Argemone Mexicana

 

  • The plant in the image is Argemone Mexicana.
  • It is also called as Mexican prickly poppy.
  • Oil extract can cause Epidemic dropsy characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, edema of the feet, and generalized anasarca.
  • Identification: Yellow flowers

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura alba: Datura alba, also known as white datura, has large trumpet-shaped white flowers and is a different plant with its own toxic properties, primarily affecting the nervous system.

 

 

Option C. Abrus precatorius: Abrus precatorius, commonly known as Rosary pea or jequirity, has distinctive red seeds with a black spot. The plant is different from Argemone mexicana.

 

 

Option D. Erthyroxylum coca: Erthyroxylum coca is the plant from which cocaine is derived. It has small white flowers and red berries, and does not resemble Argemone mexicana.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plant Argemone mexicana, identifiable by its yellow flowers and spiny leaves, is known for its toxic oil extract which can cause Epidemic dropsy.

choices.text: It is exclusively given in the deltoid
Not given after 7 days of the 1st dose of the vaccine
If human RIG is unavailable, equine is preferred

questions.text: A physician is preparing to administer post-exposure prophylaxis for a patient who has been bitten by a potentially rabid animal. Which of the following statements about the administration of rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is INCORRECT? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is exclusively given in the deltoid

 

  • Dose of Human Rabies Immunoglobulin (HRIg): 20 IU/kg body weight
  • Dose of Equine Rabies Immunoglobulin (ERIg): 40 IU/kg body weight
  • RIg must be given as soon as possible
  • RIg is NOT recommended beyond the 7th day of starting first dose of vaccine
  • RIg must never be given Intravenously
  • Entire dose of RIg (or as much as possible) must be infiltrated around the wound(s) site(s).
  • Remaining dose, if any, must be given Intramuscularly in deltoid

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) should be infiltrated around the wound site and any remaining dose given intramuscularly, preferably in the deltoid, but it is not exclusively given in the deltoid.

questions.text: Match the malignancies with the responsible genes: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Pleomorphic adenoma: This benign salivary gland tumor is associated with the overexpression of the Plag-1 proto-oncogene. Plag-1 plays a significant role in the tumorigenesis of pleomorphic adenoma, making option d the correct match.
  2. Burkitt's lymphoma: This aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma is most commonly associated with the translocation of the C-myc gene, particularly t(8;14) or t(8;22). This translocation leads to the overexpression of the C-myc oncogene, driving the proliferation of lymphoid cells, making option c the correct match.
  3. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood and is associated with amplification of the N-myc gene. N-myc plays a critical role in the aggressive behavior of neuroblastoma, making option b the correct match.
  4. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma, the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children, is associated with mutations in the Rb gene. The Rb gene is a tumor suppressor that regulates cell cycle progression, and its inactivation leads to uncontrolled cell division, making option a the correct match.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following cerclage procedures would be done in a nonpregnant female? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lash and Lash cerclage

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lash and Lash procedure is the only cerclage procedure that is done in the non-pregnant state. Vaginal procedures are preferred over laparoscopic procedure

 

Types of Cerclage Procedures (Other Options)

 

  1. Transvaginal
  2. Transabdominal

 

1. Transvaginal

 

  • McDonald suture
    • Purse string
    • Below the level of the internal os
    • Placed during pregnancy (12-14 weeks
    • Sutures removed at 37 weeks

 

 

  • Shirodkar cerclage
    • Placed during pregnancy (!2-14 weeks)
    • Bladder pushed up
    • Closer to internal os
    • More physiological than McDonald
    • Usually done if previous failed McDonald
    • A tape is inserted circumferentially near the os
    • Removed at 37 weeks

 

 

  • Wurm’s Cerclage
    • 2 sutures taken as shown in figure
    • Placed during pregnancy at 12-14 weeks
    • Removed at 37 weeks

 

 

  • Lash Cerclage
    • Done PRE-PREGNANCY
    • A defect in cervix is removed and cervix reconstructed
    • Deliver is ALWAYS by LSCS
    • Sutures not removed

 

 

2. Transabdominal:

 

  1. Could be done by laparotomy (1st introduced by Benson and Durfee) OR by Laparoscopy
  2. Preferably done pre-pregnancy but can also be done during pregnancy
  3. Done in cases of failed transvaginal cerclage procedures.
  4. Most physiological as it is highest (at the level of the cervix)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lash and Lash cerclage is the only cerclage procedure done in a nonpregnant female.

questions.text: Match the following therapeutic methods used in the management of psoriasis with their possible side effects? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

 

Correct matches

 

 

PUVA (Psoralen and Ultraviolet A)

 

  • Over 90% of cases of psoriasis are successfully treated with PUVA.
  • Both acute (erythema, blistering) and chronic side effects are associated with it.
  • Use of PUVA for an extended period is linked to non-melanoma skin cancer development (squamous cell and basal cell cancers).

 

Cyclosporine

 

  • Cyclosporine usage is primarily linked to metabolic issues, a possible increased risk of malignancy, and renal impairment (decreased GFR).
  • Due to its nephrotoxic effects, it is now uncommonly used for the maintenance of psoriasis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common therapies for psoriasis with their potential side effects:

 

  • PUVA increases the risk of skin cancer (1-c),
  • Cyclosporine is nephrotoxic (2-b),
  • Methotrexate can act as an abortifacient (3-a), and
  • Acitretin is teratogenic and can cause mucositis (4-d).

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.26-28

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 3402

choices.text: Collect using your hand and discard in drain
Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket
Collect and throw outside in the environment
Broom it and discard in dustbin

questions.text: A medical student accidentally drops a sphygmomanometer, causing mercury spill on the floor. What is the most appropriate method to manage this spill? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket

 

  • Identify visible larger mercury beads and push together using Cardboards and collect using Syringe without needle.
  • Store collected mercury beads in an air tight plastic bag and label it properly. Put all the items that were used to pick up the mercury, including index cards or cardboard, eyedropper, contaminated tape, paper towels, and zipper-type bags into the trash bag. Carefully seal the trash bag that contains the mercury contaminated waste and dispose them properly.
  • Do not use a vacuum, broom or paint brush to clean up the spill. These methods can spread the mercury to other areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate method to manage a mercury spill is to collect it using paper/cardboard and place it in a water tube or bucket, then ensure safe and proper disposal.
  • Avoid direct contact, vacuuming, or sweeping the mercury.

questions.text: Modified biophysical profile includes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NST and AFI

 

The Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes two key components: the Non-Stress Test (NST) and the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI). This abbreviated version of the BPP focuses on assessing fetal well-being through these two measures. The NST evaluates fetal heart rate patterns in response to fetal movements, while the AFI assesses the amount of amniotic fluid, which can indicate the health of the placenta and overall fetal condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NST and fetal tone: This combination is not the Modified BPP. While the NST is part of the Modified BPP, fetal tone is part of the complete Biophysical Profile but not included in the Modified BPP.

 

Option C. NST and breathing movements: Breathing movements are part of the complete Biophysical Profile, but not included in the Modified BPP, which only uses NST and AFI.

 

Option D. NST and gross fetal movements: Gross fetal movements are part of the full Biophysical Profile, but not included in the Modified BPP, which comprises only NST and AFI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes the Non-Stress Test (NST) and the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI).

 

Ref: Page no 980, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein’s procedure

 

The following surgical options are used to treat rectal prolapse:

 

This procedure involves the use of a prosthetic mesh that is placed around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory. It is performed using the abdominal approach, which is difficult but has a lower recurrence rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delorme's operation: This surgical option involves the circumferential stripping of the rectal mucosa over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures, and the excess rectal mucosa is excised. It is performed using the perineal approach and is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate than the abdominal approach.

 

Option C. Thiersch operation: This surgical option involves placing a steel wire or nylon tape around the anal canal to manage partial rectal prolapse. It is largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation, and is rarely used.

 

Option D. Altemeier's procedure: This surgical option involves prolapsing the rectum through the anal canal and performing a full-thickness resection, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. It is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ripstein's procedure is done for its management using the abdominal approach. The perineal approach is often preferred in elderly patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy. It involves surgeries such as Delorme's mucosectomy and Thiersch's wiring, which have higher recurrence rates than the abdominal approach.

questions.text: A person presents to the hospital with fever and chills. Fever profile is ordered and is found to be negative for malaria and dengue. RK-39 test is found to be positive. What is the treatment of choice? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amphotericin B

 

The RK-39 test is used to diagnose visceral leishmaniasis, which is also known as kala-azar. Visceral leishmaniasis is caused by the Leishmania parasite and is transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. The test detects antibodies against the RK-39 antigen, which is a marker for this disease.

 

In India, the first-line treatment for visceral leishmaniasis is Amphotericin B. This drug is effective in treating the disease and is preferred due to its ability to clear the infection. While other treatments like sodium stibogluconate are available, Amphotericin B is the standard treatment due to its efficacy and safety profile in the Indian context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Griseofulvin: This is an antifungal medication used to treat dermatophyte infections of the skin, hair, and nails. It is not effective against parasitic infections like leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Dapsone: This drug is primarily used to treat leprosy and certain types of dermatitis. It is not used for treating leishmaniasis.

 

Option D. Hydroxychloroquine: This medication is used for the treatment of malaria, rheumatoid arthritis, and lupus erythematosus. It is not effective against leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RK-39 test is used to diagnose visceral leishmaniasis, and the treatment of choice for visceral leishmaniasis in India is Amphotericin B

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for 8 months. A barium swallow was done and is shown in the image below. What other investigations should be done to confirm the diagnosis in this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) UGIE + manometry

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario and the barium swallow image show a bird beak sign which indicates achalasia cardia. To confirm the diagnosis, Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and manometry should be performed. Manometry is the IOC for achalasia cardia and other motility disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. UGIE + contrast enhanced CT: While useful for structural evaluation, it does not specifically assess esophageal motility.

 

Option B. UGIE + PET: Typically used for oncological assessments, not directly useful for diagnosing motility disorders.

 

Option C. UGIE + 24-hour pH monitoring: Used to diagnose gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), not directly relevant for achalasia unless GERD is also suspected.

 

Educational Objective:

In a patient being planned for induction of labor, night dose of intermediate insulin is given as planned, and the morning dose is withheld
In active labor, if RBS <70 mg%, D5 is started at 100-150 ml/h till the RBS is >100 mg%
