questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding management of diabetes in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elective C-section has no role in reducing incidence of brachial plexus injury

 

Explanation:

 

  • False statement regarding management of diabetes in pregnancy is option A.
  • The Cesarean section is found to be protective against traumatic injuries such as brachial plexus injury, in macrosomic babies born to mothers with diabetes.
  • Elective LSCS is recommended when the estimated fetal weight is > 4.5kg in diabetic mothers to reduce the incidence of birth trauma

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. In a patient being planned for induction of labor, night dose of intermediate insulin is given as planned, and the morning dose is withheld: In a planned delivery, although the bedtime dose of intermediate-acting insulin is given, it is recommended that the morning dose must be withheld

 

Insulin Management for Labor Induction or Scheduled Cesarean Delivery

 

 

Option C. In active labor, if RBS <70 mg%, D5 is started at 100-150 ml/h till the RBS is >100 mg%: In active labor, if RBS (Random blood glucose) <70 mg%, D5 (5% dextrose) is started at 100-150 ml/h till the RBS is >100 mg%. Before initiation of labor, normal saline is used for iv infusion.

 

Option D. Capillary blood glucose monitoring levels are kept at fasting- 95 mg%; 1 h postprandial- 140 mg%; 2 h postprandial: 120 mg%: Self-monitoring of capillary blood glucose is advised in a pregnant woman diagnosed with diabetes. The glucose goals recommended are:

 

  • Fasting: 95 mg/dL
  • 1 h postprandial: 140 mg/dL
  • 2 h postprandial: 120 mg/dL

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elective C-section can reduce the incidence of brachial plexus injury in pregnancies complicated by diabetes, especially in cases of fetal macrosomia.

 

Ref: Page no 2807, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Kassowitz rule is related to? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital syphilis

 

Explanation:

 

Kassowitz's rule pertains to congenital syphilis. According to this rule, if a woman with untreated syphilis has multiple pregnancies, the likelihood of congenital syphilis affecting the fetus in later pregnancies decreases. This phenomenon is observed as a result of the immune system's adaptive response and potential changes in the transmission dynamics of the infection over successive pregnancies. Therefore, the rule suggests that with each subsequent pregnancy, the outcome for the fetus improves if the infection remains untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary syphilis: Primary syphilis involves the initial chancre or ulcer at the site of infection and is not related to Kassowitz's rule, which specifically addresses outcomes in congenital syphilis.

 

Option C. Secondary syphilis: Secondary syphilis is characterized by systemic manifestations such as skin rashes and mucous membrane lesions and is not related to Kassowitz's rule.

 

Option D. Latent syphilis: Latent syphilis refers to a stage where no symptoms are present but the infection is still systemic. Kassowitz's rule is not associated with latent syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kassowitz rule states that the likelihood of congenital syphilis infection decreases with each successive pregnancy in a woman with untreated syphilis.

 

Ref: Page no 343, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder
Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests

questions.text: A genetic counsellor is discussing various types of genetic tests with a couple planning for a child. Which of the following statements accurately describes genetic screening? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder

 

Genetic screening/testing

 

  • Genetic testing is a type of medical test that identifies changes in genes, chromosomes, or proteins. 
  • It is a process to analyse blood or skin for the systematic search for persons with a particular genotype in a defined population (usually invasive procedures)
  • In order to locate this faulty gene, scientists search for variations in larger pieces of DNA called "markers", latter are found nearby the DNA and become the basis of genetic screening
  • The results of a genetic test can confirm or rule out a suspected genetic condition or help determine a person's chance of developing or passing on a genetic. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests: Incorrect. Screening tests assess risk and are not as definitive as diagnostic tests, which provide a precise diagnosis.

 

Option C. Screening requires genetic mapping: Incorrect. Genetic screening does not necessarily involve genetic mapping, which is a detailed analysis of the entire genome.

 

Option D. Involve invasive procedures: Incorrect. Screening tests can often be performed using non-invasive methods such as blood or saliva samples, although some genetic tests may require invasive procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genetic screening tests are used to define the risk of passing on a genetic disorder and can help determine the likelihood of developing a genetic condition.
  • They are not as definitive as diagnostic tests and do not necessarily involve invasive procedures or genetic mapping.

questions.text: The following clinical examination was performed. What lesion would cause an exaggerated reflex? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper motor neuron

 

The clinical examination shown in the image involves testing the ankle jerk reflex, which is a deep tendon reflex. Exaggerated or hyperactive reflexes are typically a sign of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. UMN lesions occur in the neural pathways above the level of the anterior horn cell in the spinal cord, which includes the brain and the spinal cord itself. When these pathways are damaged, there is a loss of inhibitory control over the lower motor neurons, leading to hyperreflexia (exaggerated reflexes).

 

Upper motor neuron lesions are characterized by:

 

  • Hyperreflexia (exaggerated reflexes)
  • Spasticity
  • Positive Babinski sign
  • Weakness without significant muscle atrophy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyneuropathy: This condition affects multiple peripheral nerves and is typically associated with diminished or absent reflexes rather than exaggerated reflexes.

 

Option B. Radiculopathy: Damage to the nerve roots also results in lower motor neuron signs, including reduced reflexes and weakness in the distribution of the affected nerve root.

 

Option D. Lower motor neuron: Lesions here cause diminished or absent reflexes due to direct damage to the anterior horn cells or peripheral nerves that innervate muscles.

 

Educational Objective:


Exaggerated reflexes, such as an exaggerated ankle jerk reflex, are indicative of an upper motor neuron lesion. Lower motor neuron lesions, including those caused by polyneuropathy and radiculopathy, typically result in diminished or absent reflexes.

questions.text: All of the following features are observed in pleomorphic adenoma except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perineural invasion

 

Perineural invasion is not seen in pleomorphic adenoma.

 

 

Note - Perineural invasion is seen in malignant salivary gland tumors like adenoid cystic carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myoepithelial cells: Present in pleomorphic adenomas, contributing to the tumor's mixed epithelial and mesenchymal characteristics.

 

Option B. Keratin pearls: While not typically a feature of pleomorphic adenomas, the presence of keratin can be associated with the epithelial component. However, keratin pearls are more characteristic of squamous cell carcinomas.

 

Option C. Chondroid differentiation: A hallmark of pleomorphic adenomas, where the tumor shows cartilaginous differentiation, often contributing to its benign nature.

 

Educational Objective:


Pleomorphic adenomas are characterized by a mixture of epithelial and mesenchymal components, including myoepithelial cells and chondroid differentiation, but they do not exhibit perineural invasion, which is more typical of malignant salivary gland tumors.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1436-1437

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibitor in the graph?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive inhibitor

 

Explanation:

 

This is a Lineweaver-Burk plot of enzyme kinetics, with 1/v (inverse of velocity) on the Y-axis and 1/[S] (inverse of substrate concentration) on the X-axis. The red line represents the inhibitor, and the blue line represents the normal substrate.

 

In the presence of a competitive inhibitor, the Km (Michaelis constant) increases while the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged. This is evident in the graph where the slope increases, indicating an increased Km, but the Y-intercept, representing 1/Vmax, stays the same.

 

For non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km remains unchanged. This would be shown by an increase in the Y-intercept, which is not the case here.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-competitive inhibitor: In non-competitive inhibition, the Vmax decreases while the Km remains unchanged. This would be reflected in the graph by an increased Y-intercept (1/Vmax) while the slope remains the same, which is not observed here.

 

Option C. Allosteric inhibitor: Allosteric inhibitors bind to a site other than the active site and can either increase or decrease enzyme activity, affecting both Km and Vmax. The specific effects depend on the nature of the allosteric inhibition, which is not represented by the given Lineweaver-Burk plot.

 

Option D. Uncompetitive inhibitor: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, decreasing both Km and Vmax. This would be shown by parallel lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, which is not seen in the provided graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibitors increase the Km without affecting the Vmax, which is shown by an increase in the slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot without changing the Y-intercept.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 77

choices.text: Datura – Abrin
Opium- Atropine
Nux vomica - Strychnine
Abrus precatorius – Thebaine

questions.text: Which of these is the correct match of plant poisons and their active principles: (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nux vomica- Strychnine

 

  • Nux vomica contains Strychnine and brucine as its active principles. Strychnine is a highly toxic alkaloid used as a pesticide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura – Abrin

 

  • Datura contains Atropine, Hyoscyamine, and Scopolamine. Abrin is the toxic principle of Abrus precatorius (rosary pea).

 

Option B. Opium - Atropine

 

  • Opium contains Morphine, Codeine, and Thebaine. Atropine is the active principle of Datura.

 

Option D. Abrus precatorius – Thebaine

 

  • Abrus precatorius contains Abrin. Thebaine is an alkaloid found in Opium.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Periampullary carcinoma

 

The most probable diagnosis in this patient is periampullary carcinoma.

 

Here are the characteristic features of periampullary carcinoma:

 

  • Arises from the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater
  • Presents with jaundice that intermittently waxes and wanes due to partial relief of obstruction to bile ducts whenever the tumor undergoes necrosis and sloughing
  • Other symptoms include weight loss, pain, nausea, vomiting, pruritus, fever, and gastrointestinal bleeding
  • A three-phase CT scan is recommended for diagnosis- which shows double duct sign (dilated CBD and pancreatic duct).
  • Management includes resection, along with chemotherapy/chemoradiotherapy

 

Periampullary carcinoma refers to cancers that arise in the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater, where the bile duct and pancreatic duct converge before entering the duodenum. These tumors can obstruct both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct, leading to intermittent or waxing and waning jaundice. The anatomical location of periampullary carcinomas and double duct sign on CT makes them a likely cause in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholangiocarcinoma: Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer that originates in the bile ducts. While it can cause obstructive jaundice, it typically presents with a more gradual and progressive course of symptoms. It may cause dilatation of the bile ducts, but waxing and waning jaundice is less characteristic of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Common bile duct stone: While a common bile duct stone can cause obstructive jaundice, it typically leads to a more acute presentation with sudden onset of symptoms. Waxing and waning jaundice is not a common feature of common bile duct stones.

 

Option D. Head of pancreas carcinoma: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas, also known as pancreatic head carcinoma, can obstruct the common bile duct and cause jaundice. However, it tends to present with a more persistent and progressive form of jaundice rather than waxing and waning symptoms, as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periampullary carcinoma (option B) is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination due to its anatomical location and its potential to obstruct both ducts.

choices.text: Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease
Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis
Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition
Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease (IBD): (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease

 

Crohn's disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus. It is characterized by a patchy distribution of inflammation, which is often transmural (affecting the entire thickness of the bowel wall). Skeletions, also known as skip lesions, are a hallmark feature of Crohn's disease, where areas of inflamed tissue are interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease typically involves transmural inflammation, meaning it affects all layers of the bowel wall. On the other hand, ulcerative colitis is characterized by inflammation that is limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition: While there are genetic factors associated with IBD, such as mutations in the NOD2/CARD15 gene linked to Crohn's disease, the overall genetic predisposition is not considered strong. Environmental factors play a more significant role in the development of IBD.

 

Option D. Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract and is not curable by surgical resection. Surgery can help manage symptoms and complications but does not cure the disease. Ulcerative colitis, however, can be cured by surgical removal of the colon and rectum (total proctocolectomy).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Skepletions (skip lesions) are a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease, distinguishing it from ulcerative colitis

questions.text: A patient, who is a known case of HIV with a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm, presents with 5 days of cough and high-grade fever without chills and rigors. There is no history of diarrhea, vomiting, or nuchal rigidity. Chest x-ray is normal. What treatment will you give? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Co-trimoxazole only

 

In a patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm presenting with symptoms such as cough and fever, but with a normal chest x-ray, Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a likely diagnosis. PCP is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients, especially when the CD4 count is below 200 cells/cu.mm.

 

The treatment of choice for PCP is co-trimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole). It is essential to start treatment empirically in suspected cases of PCP because delayed treatment can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. The dose of co-trimoxazole is typically higher for treating PCP than for prophylaxis.

 

Steroids are indicated in severe cases of PCP to reduce inflammation, specifically if the patient has hypoxemia (PaO2 < 70 mmHg) or an alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient > 35 mmHg. In this scenario, there is no data indicating severe disease, so co-trimoxazole alone is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid + Azithromycin: This combination is used for bacterial pneumonia, not PCP. Given the normal chest x-ray and the patient's clinical presentation, bacterial pneumonia is less likely.

 

Option B. Co-trimoxazole + steroids: Steroids are added in severe cases of PCP. However, there is no evidence in this case of severe hypoxemia or an increased A-a gradient to justify the use of steroids along with co-trimoxazole.

 

Option D. Antitubercular treatment: There is no indication from the clinical presentation or the normal chest x-ray that the patient has tuberculosis. Antitubercular treatment is therefore not appropriate in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HIV patients with a CD4 count below 200 cells/cu.mm and presenting with cough and fever but a normal chest x-ray, co-trimoxazole is the first-line treatment for suspected PCP

 

Note - For a patient with a CD4 count of 200 and lower respiratory tract symptoms:

 

  • PCP Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray is normal or negative.
  • Bacterial Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray shows consolidation or examination reveals bronchial breath sounds.

choices.text: Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia
Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia
Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia
Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF

questions.text: All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except option A. There is reduced or absent prostacyclin (PGI,) production with increased production of thromboxane (TXA,) and reduced ratio of prostacyclin: thromboxane in preeclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia: Endothelial cell dysfunction is another etiology. Injured or activated endothelial cells may produce less nitric oxide and may secrete substances that promote coagulation and vasopressor sensitivity.

 

Option C. Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia: Vasospasm has long been associated with preeclampsia. Systemic endothelial activation causes vasospasm, which elevates resistance to produce hypertension. With diminished blood flow because of maldistribution from vasospasm and interstitial leakage, ischemia of the surrounding tissues can cause necrosis, hemorrhage, and other end-organ disturbances.

 

Option D. Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF:

 

Angiogenic Factors:

 

  • Placental vasculogenesis is evident 21 days after conception. Two antiangiogenic peptides that are increased
    • Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1)
    • Soluble endoglin (s-eng)
  • Factors that are decreased are
    • PlGF
    • PAPP-A
    • VEGF

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preeclampsia, the prostacyclin: thromboxane ratio is decreased due to increased thromboxane A2 and decreased prostacyclin (PGI2).

 

Ref: Page no 1802, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Most common pattern of involvement of Pott’s spine is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paradiscal

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

 

A. Paradiscal: This is the commonest type. In this, the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae along with the intervening disc are affected.

 

 

B. Central: In this type, the body of a single vertebra is affected. This leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra. The nearby disc may be normal. The collapse may be a ‘wedging’ or ‘concertina’ collapse; wedging being more common.

 

C. Anterior: In this type, infection is localised to the anterior part of the vertebral body. The infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.

 

D. Posterior: This is the least common type. In this type, the posterior complex of the vertebra, i.e., the pedicle, lamina, spinous process and transverse process are affected.

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common > central type > anterior type > appendiceal type (involving pedicle, lamina, and less commonly transverse process, 2nd least common is spinous process and rarest variety is synovitis of facet joints).
  • Clinical features: 
    • Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest and 1st symptom.
    • Tenderness is the earliest sign.
    • Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension – Coin test
    • Earliest sign of  neurological deficit – increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response.
    • The prominence of 2-3 spinous process, called angular kyphosis is commonest in tuberculosis because of 2 contiguous vertebra involved with paradiscal destruction.
    • In the thoracic region, kyphosis is most marked because of normal kyphotic curvature.

 

 

  • Tuberculosis is the most common cause of cold abscess.
  • Psoas abscess can give rise to pseudo-hip flexion deformity
  • Paraplegia occurs most often in upper thoracic region.∙
  • Early onset paresis is due to inflammatory edema, granulation tissue, an abscess, caseous material. It has good prognosis.
  • Late onset paresis is due to increasing deformity or reactivation of disease, bony sequestrum, stenosis of the vertebral canal, fibrosis or vascular insufficiency and has poor prognosis.
  • Sequelae of TB spine is usually bony ankylosis.

 

  • Imaging:
  • Plain radiograph: 
    • Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm.
    • Reduction of disc space
    • Vertebral body destruction
    • Paravertebral abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.
    • Widening of mediastinum
       
  • CT scan: 
    • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
       
  • MRI:
    • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
    • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.

 

 

  • Biopsy:
    • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.

 

  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:
    • Stage 1: no neural complaint; increased reflexes
    • Stage 2: weakness but can walk with support
    • Stage 3: non-ambulatory or has sensory loss <50%
    • Stage 4: bowel/bladder involvement or sensory loss >50%
       
       
  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India
    • Treatment is done with antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on non-operative management but if indications of surgery exists  then, surgery needs to be done.
    • Stage-wise Treatment:
      • Stage 1: ATT + rest + monthly neural examination
      • Stage 2: ATT + rest + weekly neural examination
      • Stage 3: ATT + rest + daily neural examination
      • Stage 4: ATT + Decompression and bone grafting
         
    • ATT: 
      • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
      • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
         
    • Indications of surgery: 
      • Bowel bladder involvement
      • Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
      • No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks
         
  • Surgical options for most of the cases aren anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Hong Kong operation is also carried out.
  • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed)

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.
     

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common pattern of involvement followed by central type followed by anterior type followed by the posterior type.

questions.text: Tongue fasciculations are seen in: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spinal muscular atrophy

 

Tongue fasciculations are indicative of a lower motor neuron lesion, often associated with disorders that affect the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord or the motor neurons in the brainstem.

 

Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA): This condition is characterized by the degeneration of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and motor nuclei in the lower brainstem. This degeneration leads to muscle weakness and atrophy, including the muscles of the tongue, resulting in tongue fasciculations. SMA is divided into several types based on the age of onset and severity, but fasciculations are a common feature across these types.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Guillain-Barre syndrome: This is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy that primarily affects the peripheral nerves. It does not typically cause fasciculations, as it is more associated with rapidly progressive weakness and areflexia.

 

Option C. Duchenne muscular dystrophy: This is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness. It primarily affects the skeletal muscles, and while it leads to muscle weakness, it does not typically cause fasciculations.

 

Option D. Myasthenia gravis: This is an autoimmune disorder affecting the neuromuscular junction. It leads to fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability but does not involve lower motor neurons or cause fasciculations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tongue fasciculations are a clinical sign associated with spinal muscular atrophy due to the involvement of lower motor neurons

questions.text: A female patient presents to the hospital with palpitations. Her vitals are stable, and the ECG shows the following. Which of the following is used as first-line management to treat the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine

 

The patient's ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia. This type of tachycardia, in a stable patient, is initially managed with vagal maneuvers such as carotid sinus massage or the Valsalva maneuver. These maneuvers aim to increase parasympathetic tone and slow conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node. If vagal maneuvers are ineffective or not feasible, the next step is to administer an AV nodal blocker.

 

Adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment for stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia. It works by transiently blocking the AV node, thereby interrupting the re-entrant circuit responsible for the tachycardia. The initial dose of adenosine is 6 mg administered rapidly IV push, followed by a 10 ml saline flush. If the tachycardia persists, additional doses of 12 mg may be given, with a maximum cumulative dose of 30 mg. Adenosine has a very short half-life of approximately 8 to 10 seconds, necessitating rapid (IV push) administration and immediate follow-up with normal saline to ensure efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is used for the treatment of various types of arrhythmias, including wide complex tachycardias (regular and monomorphic rhythm).

 

Option B. DC Cardioversion: Direct current (DC) cardioversion is used in cases of hemodynamic instability or when pharmacological treatment fails. It is not the first-line treatment for a stable patient presenting with regular narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that can be used to manage atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular rhythm, because in that case adenosine is contraindicated).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia, adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left hypoactive labyrinth

 

  • A left hypoactive labyrinth is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features.
  • Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component.
  • The fast component denotes the direction of the nystagmus.
  • Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis, and trauma to the labyrinth cause nystagmus to the healthy side.
  • Serous labyrinthitis (irritative lesion) leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior canal BPPV: Characterized by positional vertigo and typically vertical nystagmus, related to the posterior semicircular canal.

 

Option B. Superior canal BPPV: Also known as anterior canal BPPV, would cause primarily vertically oriented nystagmus, not horizontal.

 

Option C. Right hypoactive labyrinth: Would produce nystagmus with the slow component towards the right and the fast component towards the left, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The direction of the slow and fast components of nystagmus is crucial in diagnosing the affected side in vestibular disorders. A left hypoactive labyrinth leads to nystagmus with a fast component to the right, matching the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 43

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about the internal capsule?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Charcot's artery supplies the posterior limb.
  2. Retrolenticular part of the internal capsule contains optic radiation.
  3. Anterior limb of the capsule contains corticospinal tract fibers of the upper limb and face.
  4. Internal capsule has projection fibers.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 4

 

Explanation:

 

The internal capsule is primarily composed of projection fibers that connect the cortex to other parts of the brain or spinal cord. The internal capsule can be divided into three parts: anterior limb, genu, and posterior limb. Lesions in these areas can result in different neurological deficits.

 

  • The anterior limb contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the thalamus and basal ganglia, and lesions here can cause motor and behavioral changes. Fronto pontine fibers also pass via anterior limb.
  • The genu contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the contralateral motor cortex, and lesions here can cause facial weakness and hemiparesis. Fronto pontine and cortico nuclear fibers pass via genu.
  • The posterior limb contains fibers that connect the sensory and motor cortices to the brainstem and spinal cord, and lesions here can cause sensory and motor deficits Fronto pontine, cortico spinal fir trunk, upper as well as lower limbs via posterior limb..

 

The retrolenticular part of the internal capsule carries fibers primarily from the optic radiation, which is a bundle of axons that originate from the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus and terminate in the visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Lesions in this area can result in visual field deficits, such as homonymous hemianopia, superior or inferior quadrantanopia. (Parieto pontine and occipito pontine fibers also pass via retrolentiform) Charcots artery supplies the genu and posterior limb. Hence statement 1, 2 and 4 correct.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 4: Internal capsule has projection fibers - The internal capsule contains a large collection of projection fibers that include both ascending sensory and descending motor pathways. These fibers connect the cerebral cortex with the brainstem and spinal cord, conveying sensory information to the cortex and motor commands away from the cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal capsule, a key white matter structure in the brain, contains Charcot's artery-supplied posterior limb, optic radiation in the retrolenticular part, and is primarily composed of projection fibers linking the cortex with the brainstem and spinal cord. Misinformation about the anterior limb's contents highlights the complexity and specificity of its neural pathways.

questions.text: An HIV patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed. What is the likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurocysticercosis

 

Explanation:

 

The MRI brain image shows multiple cyst-like lesions within the brain, which are characteristic of neurocysticercosis, often described as a "starry sky" appearance. Neurocysticercosis is an infection caused by the larvae of the pork tapeworm, Taenia solium. These lesions are typically cystic with a scolex (head of the larva) visible within the cysts, which is a diagnostic feature. This condition is common in areas where pork is commonly consumed and sanitation practices are poor, and it can lead to serious neurological symptoms like the ones presented by the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculoma: Generally appears as well-defined, enhancing masses on MRI, which are not specifically indicated by the cystic nature of the lesions seen in this image.

 

Option C. Toxoplasmosis: Common in HIV patients, but typically presents as multiple ring-enhancing lesions rather than the cystic lesions with a clear scolex seen here.

 

Option D. Cryptococcomas: Typically appear as gelatinous masses in the brain and would not usually present with the clear, cystic appearance with scoleces indicative of parasitic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis should be considered in patients presenting with multiple cystic brain lesions, especially in contexts of headache and altered mental status, where the history and radiological findings suggest the presence of cysts with scoleces typical of tapeworm larvae.

questions.text:
Chronic HBV infection would be consistent with which of the following serology? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. HBsAg
  2. Anti-HBsAg
  3. Anti-HBcAg
  4. HBV DNA
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

 

Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): This antibody appears after the infection has been cleared or following successful vaccination. It indicates immunity to HBV. In chronic HBV infection, this antibody is not present since the surface antigen is still active.

 

Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is defined by the persistence of the surface antigen (HBsAg) for more than six months. The presence of HBsAg indicates an active HBV infection.

 

Serological markers:

 

1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This antigen indicates that the person is infectious. It is found in the blood during acute and chronic HBV infection. The presence of HBsAg for more than six months defines chronic HBV infection.

 

3. Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): This antibody indicates previous or ongoing infection with HBV. In chronic infection, the IgG fraction of anti-HBc is usually present.

 

4. HBV DNA: The presence of HBV DNA in the blood indicates active viral replication. It is usually detectable in chronic HBV infection, although the levels can vary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic HBV infection is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg, the presence of Anti-HBc, and usually detectable HBV DNA. Anti-HBs is not present in chronic HBV infection as it indicates immunity.

questions.text: In MSUD (Maple Syrup Urine disorder) which of the following is not restricted:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methionine

 

  • Methionine is not restricted in MSUD. MSUD is characterized by the inability to break down three specific branched-chain amino acids: Leucine, Isoleucine, and Valine. Methionine is not one of the amino acids that are restricted in the diet of individuals with MSUD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valine: Valine is one of the amino acids restricted in MSUD. People with MSUD need to limit their intake of Valine as their bodies cannot properly metabolize it.

 

Option C. Leucine: Leucine is another amino acid that is restricted in MSUD. It is one of the three branched-chain amino acids that individuals with MSUD need to limit in their diet.

 

Option D. Isoleucine: Isoleucine is also restricted in MSUD. Like Valine and Leucine, Isoleucine is a branched-chain amino acid that individuals with MSUD need to restrict to manage the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched Chain Keto-acid Decarboxylase resulting in defect in oxidative decarboxylation and catabolism of branched chain amino acids Valine, Isoleucine and leucine. As a result, these amino acids accumulate and are excreted in urine. So, for the treatment, these BCAA should be restricted in diet.

 

Methionine is a sulphur containing amino acid and do not require this enzyme for its metabolism. So, its restriction is not required in MSUD.  

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 290

questions.text: A farmer presented with history of ingestion of an unknown substance. He had increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and tachycardia. What is the drug of choice for treatment? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Atropine

 

The above clinical scenario suggests organophosphate poisoning.

 

DOC for treatment- Atropine.

 

Though pralidoxime can also be given, but the main drug of choice is Atropine

 

 

SYMPTOMS:

 

 

MANAGEMENT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium gluconate: Calcium gluconate is used in cases of calcium deficiency or hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is a reactivator of acetylcholinesterase and is used in combination with atropine to treat organophosphate poisoning. However, it is not the primary drug of choice; atropine is.

 

Option D. Obidoxime: Obidoxime is also an acetylcholinesterase reactivator similar to pralidoxime, used in organophosphate poisoning, but not the primary drug of choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of organophosphate poisoning presenting with symptoms like increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and tachycardia, Atropine is the primary drug of choice for treatment. It acts by competitively inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine.

questions.text:
Which of the following cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Stellate cells

2. Basket cells

3. Purkinje cells

4. Granular cells
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum contains stellate and basket cells.

 

The molecular layer is one of the three layers of the cerebellar cortex, along with the granular layer and the Purkinje cell layer. It is involved in the processing of sensory information, as well as motor planning and coordination. The stellate and basket cells within the molecular layer provide inhibitory feedback to the Purkinje cells, which are the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

 

The parallel fibres, which originate from granule cells in the granular layer, run perpendicular to the Purkinje cell dendrites and provide excitatory input to the molecular layer. As the parallel fibres traverse the molecular layer, they make multiple synapses with the dendrites of Purkinje cells, where inhibitory synapses are formed. This allows the Purkinje cells to integrate the incoming excitatory and inhibitory signals and adjust their output accordingly.

 

Overall, the molecular layer plays a crucial role in the cerebellar circuitry and contributes to the precision of motor movements and balance.

 

 

1. Stellate cells:

  • Location: Stellate cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are inhibitory interneurons that primarily release GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and inhibit the dendrites of Purkinje cells.
     

2. Basket cells:

  • Location: Basket cells are also located in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are another type of inhibitory interneuron. The axons of basket cells form "baskets" around the cell bodies of Purkinje cells, releasing GABA and inhibiting them.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Purkinje cells:

  • Location: Purkinje cells form their own distinct layer known as the Purkinje cell layer, which is situated between the molecular layer and the granular layer.
  • Function: These cells are the primary output neurons of the cerebellar cortex. They have large, flattened dendritic trees that extend into the molecular layer, receiving inputs from climbing fibers and parallel fibers. The axons of Purkinje cells send inhibitory projections to the cerebellar nuclei.
     

4. Granular cells:

  • Location: Granular cells are present in the granular layer, which is the innermost layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • Function: These cells receive inputs from mossy fibers, which originate from various brainstem nuclei and the spinal cord. Granular cells send their axons into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate to form parallel fibers. These parallel fibers synapse onto the dendrites of Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum primarily contains stellate and basket cells. This layer is one of three distinct layers of the cerebellar cortex and is crucial for integrating sensory and motor information to refine motor coordination and balance.

questions.text: Identify the disorder with X-linked dominant inheritance: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

 

Rett syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.

 

Rett syndrome:

 

 

Other examples of XLD disorders include Vitamin D Independent Rickets, Aicardi Syndrome, Hypophosphatemic Rickets, Incontinentia pigmenti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD): Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is inherited in X linked recessive pattern. It is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene and predominantly affects boys, leading to progressive muscle weakness and wasting.

Option C. Huntington's disease: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, leading to motor dysfunction, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms.           

 

Option D. Tuberous sclerosis: Tuberous sclerosis / Bournville disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, characterized by the development of benign tumors in multiple organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder most commonly seen in girls, characterized by microcephaly, regression of motor milestones, developmental delay, and stereotyped movements.

questions.text: What could be the most probable diagnosis for a 26-year-old woman who was brought to the ER at Hospital after a car accident, with a stable blood pressure, a GCS score of 3, and a normal non-contrast CT scan? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse axonal injury

 

The patient's clinical presentation suggests the possibility of diffuse axonal injury, which occurs when the brain experiences shearing forces, often from rotational acceleration within the skull. This can result in damage to the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, fornix, and internal and external capsule, leading to disruption of axons and microvasculature.

 

 Automobile accidents are the most common cause of diffuse axonal injury, and patients often remain unconscious from the moment of impact until death. Multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution are typical of diffuse axonal injury, and CT scans may appear normal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), particularly susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI), is the preferred imaging modality for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury, and can reveal small regions of susceptibility artifact or hemorrhage. Subdural hemorrhage, extradural hemorrhage, and cerebral contusion are other potential traumatic brain injuries that can present with different imaging features and may require different treatments.

 

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a type of traumatic brain injury that results from the shearing forces during rapid deceleration or rotational head trauma. It can cause profound neurological impairment, even with a seemingly normal CT scan early on. A GCS score of 3 is indicative of severe brain injury, and DAI is a common cause of such a presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hemorrhage: Subdural hemorrhage is associated with bleeding between the brain and its outermost covering (the dura mater). While it can result from head trauma, it typically presents with altered mental status, neurological deficits, or focal symptoms. A GCS score of 3 and a normal non-contrast CT scan make this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Extradural hemorrhage: It can lead to rapid neurological deterioration, often with a lucid interval after the injury. A normal non-contrast CT scan is inconsistent with an acute extradural hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Cerebral contusion: Cerebral contusions are focal brain injuries characterized by bruising of the brain tissue. They can occur in head trauma and may present with neurological deficits or focal symptoms. However, a normal non-contrast CT scan would typically not rule out a cerebral contusion if it's a small or subtle contusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's presentation with a GCS score of 3 and a normal non-contrast CT scan, the most probable diagnosis is diffuse axonal injury (option C), which can result in severe neurological impairment despite a normal initial CT scan.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is the new FDA approved immune check point inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pembrolizumab

 

The new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium is Pembrolizumab.

 

Pembrolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against PD-1 receptor (Programmed Death Receptor) that can be used for many cancers including endometrial carcinoma. Some of the other cancers where it is useful are:

 

  • Metastatic urothelial cancer
  • Refractory melanoma
  • Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Merkel cell cancer
  • Chemotherapy Refractory Head and Neck Cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab: is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and is used for the treatment of advanced melanoma and relapsed/refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option C. Trastuzumab: is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the HER2 receptor. It is used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Option D. Ipilimumab: is a monoclonal antibody that binds to cytotoxic T lymphocyte-associated Protein 4 (CTLA-4) and is approved for the treatment of late-stage melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pembrolizumab is the new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium. It works by blocking the PD-1 receptor, enhancing the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells. It is also used for treating several other cancers, including metastatic urothelial cancer, refractory melanoma, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Merkel cell cancer, and chemotherapy-refractory head and neck cancer.

choices.text: Tingling and numbness of hands and feet

questions.text: Amongst the options given below, which of these are not seen in cocaine poisoning? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Constricted pupils and bradycardia

 

Dilated pupils and tachycardia is seen with cocaine ingestion as it is a sympathomimetic (stimulant).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tingling and numbness of hands and feet: This is a common symptom due to the neurological effects of cocaine.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Cocaine causes vasoconstriction and increased heart rate, leading to hypertension.

 

Option D. Hyperthermia: Increased body temperature is a common finding due to excessive sympathetic stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of cocaine intoxication:

 

  • Early features – Stage of excitement:
  • Dry mouth, dysphagia, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, dilated pupils, and increased temperature followed by convulsions, hallucinations, tingling, and numbness in the hands and feet.
  • Late features – Stage of depression – Respiration is depressed, excessive sweating, collapse, convulsions, and death.
  • Magnan’s symptoms / Cocaine bugs - Chronic cocaine users may have the feeling of insects crawling on their skin or the presence of grains of sand under the skin.
  • Ulceration of nasal septum seen due to sniffing cocaine in chronic abuse

questions.text: A patient presents with perioral numbness, tingling, and tetany. All the following conditions can lead to this, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D toxicity

 

Vitamin D toxicity leads to hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia. Excessive vitamin D increases calcium absorption from the gastrointestinal tract and mobilizes calcium from bones, leading to elevated serum calcium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Perioral numbness, tingling, and tetany are symptoms indicative of hypocalcemia. Various conditions can lead to hypocalcemia, each through different mechanisms:

 

Option B. Acute Pancreatitis: This condition can lead to hypocalcemia due to the sequestration of calcium in the inflamed pancreatic tissue and the formation of calcium soaps.

 

Option C. Chronic Kidney Disease: CKD results in hypocalcemia primarily due to decreased production of calcitriol (active vitamin D). The kidneys are unable to convert 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, leading to decreased calcium absorption in the gut.

 

Option D. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition, often resulting from surgical removal or damage to the parathyroid glands, leads to decreased production of parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH is crucial for calcium homeostasis, and its deficiency results in hypocalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D toxicity causes hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia, distinguishing it from other conditions that can lead to hypocalcemia.

choices.text: Fluctuant swelling in the hip
Cold abscess can develop from Pott's abscess
Pain on passive extension of hip joint is seen in patients and elderly
All of the above

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Psoas abscess are true? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Psoas abscess is characterized by a collection of pus in the iliopsoas muscle compartment, often resulting from an infection that may either be primary (from hematogenous spread) or secondary (from local extension). Here's why all the provided statements are true:

 

  • Fluctuant swelling in the hip: Psoas abscess may present as a fluctuant swelling that is palpable in the hip or groin area due to the proximity of the psoas muscle to these regions.
  • Cold abscess can develop from Pott's abscess: A Pott’s abscess, which is a form of spinal tuberculosis, can lead to the formation of a cold abscess due to spread of infection down to the psoas muscle along the sheath. This is considered a secondary psoas abscess.
  • Pain on passive extension of hip joint is seen in patients and elderly: This pain is due to the irritation of the psoas muscle, which is involved in hip flexion. Extension of the hip stretches the inflamed psoas muscle, causing pain.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fluctuant swelling in the hip: Directly related to the local presentation of a psoas abscess.

 

Option B. Cold abscess can develop from Pott's abscess: Demonstrates the connection between specific infections like tuberculosis and the development of certain types of abscesses.

 

Option C. Pain on passive extension of hip joint: This symptom reflects the physical discomfort caused by the stretching of the inflamed psoas muscle, common in psoas abscess due to its anatomical positioning and function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the clinical presentation and etiology of psoas abscess, particularly recognizing that it can manifest with local hip symptoms, have a connection to spinal tuberculosis (Pott's abscess), and cause specific movement-related pain due to its anatomical location and function

questions.text: How is neurogenic shock characterized? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypotension + Bradycardia.

 

Neurogenic shock is characterized by hypotension (low blood pressure) and bradycardia (slow heart rate). This condition is a result of the disruption of the sympathetic nervous system, which often occurs due to a spinal cord injury, particularly affecting the cervical or high thoracic regions. The loss of sympathetic tone leads to unopposed parasympathetic activity, causing widespread vasodilation, decreased systemic vascular resistance, and reduced heart rate, all contributing to decreased cardiac output and blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertension + Tachycardia: This combination is not typical of neurogenic shock; it is more likely seen in conditions involving excess sympathetic activity.

 

Option B. Hypotension + Tachycardia: This is more typical of other forms of shock, such as hemorrhagic or septic, where compensatory mechanisms increase heart rate to maintain cardiac output despite low blood volume or vasodilation.

 

Option D. Hypertension + Bradycardia: This combination is also incorrect for neurogenic shock. It could be seen in other medical scenarios, such as intracranial pressure increases, but not typically in shock states.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurogenic shock should be recognized by its key characteristics of hypotension and bradycardia, resulting from a loss of sympathetic tone and unopposed parasympathetic activity due to spinal cord injury.

choices.text: 48 hours
70 hours
90 hours
120 hours

questions.text: The half-life of letrozole is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 48 hours

 

  • The half-life of letrozole is 48 hours.
  • Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor which is used in the treatment of ER +ve breast cancers in post-menopausal women.
  • It is also the DOC for treating infertility due to anovulation in PCOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of letrozole is 48 hours. It is an aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of ER+ breast cancer in post-menopausal women and as the drug of choice for treating infertility due to anovulation in women with PCOS.

questions.text: Phospholipase C acts via which of the following G protein-coupled receptors?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Gq 

 

Phospholipase C acts via the Gq type of G protein-coupled receptors. It leads to the activation of the IP3-DAG pathway. The receptors that act via this pathway include the receptors of H1, α1, M1, V1, M3, Angiotensin II, Gastrin, GnRH, Oxytocin and TRH.


Important points about GPCR:

 

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times (heptahelical). Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gp, Gq, and Go. GPCRs act via various second messengers. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

 

  • Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase and thus increase in cAMP.
  • Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and thus decrease in cAMP.
  • Go causes Ca2+ channel inhibition.
  • Gq causes activation of phospholipase C which generates the second messengers inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). It helps in mobilizing Ca2+ form the endoplasmic reticulum stores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phospholipase C (PLC) is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, which in turn generate the second messengers IP3 and DAG, leading to various downstream effects, including the mobilization of calcium ions from intracellular stores.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on first-line antitubercular drugs. Which of the following drug acts by inhibiting the synthesis of the marked layer shown by arrow in the image?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Isoniazid

 

Isoniazid is activated by Catalase Peroxidase and it acts by blocking the mycolic acid synthesis. It is a bactericidal drug that is effective against both intracellular and extracellular bacteria that are actively replicating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin: It is the most bactericidal drug, that is effective against intra as well as extracellular bacteria. It acts by blocking RNA polymerase.


Option C. Pyrazinamide: It is also bactericidal, that is effective mainly against intracellular bacteria. It acts by blocking fatty acid synthase.


Option D. Ethambutol: It is a bacteriostatic 1st line anti-tubercular drug that acts against both intra and extracellular bacteria by blocking arabinosyl transferase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoniazid acts by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid, a critical component of the mycobacterial cell wall, making it an effective first-line treatment for tuberculosis. The other first-line drugs have different mechanisms of action, such as inhibiting RNA polymerase (rifampicin), blocking fatty acid synthase (pyrazinamide), and inhibiting arabinosyl transferase (ethambutol).

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady came to psychiatry OPD with symptoms of hypomania. There is a past history of maniac episode. Now, she is planning to conceive. Which of the following drug is maximum teratogenic to the fetus?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Valproate

 

  • Valproate is the most teratogenic drug among the drugs used in bipolar disorder and anti-epileptic medications. It causes congenital anomalies like neural tube defects (spina bifida), cleft lip and cleft palate, and cardiac anomalies. It also contributes to poor cognitive development in children.
  • Although lithium is also teratogenic and can cause Ebstein anomaly in the fetus, but it is less teratogenic than valproate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: This medication is also used to treat bipolar disorder and epilepsy, but it has a lower risk of teratogenic effects compared to valproate. The risk of major congenital malformations with lamotrigine is relatively low.

 

Option C. Oxcarbazepine: Used to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder, oxcarbazepine has a moderate risk of teratogenic effects, but it is still considered less teratogenic than valproate.

 

Option D. Olanzapine: This antipsychotic medication is used for bipolar disorder and schizophrenia. While there are some risks associated with its use during pregnancy, including potential metabolic complications, it is not considered as teratogenic as valproate.

 

Additional Note on Lithium

 

Although lithium is also used to treat bipolar disorder and is known to be teratogenic, causing conditions like Ebstein's anomaly (a heart defect), its teratogenic risk is considered lower than that of valproate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valproate is the most teratogenic drug among the options listed, causing significant congenital anomalies such as neural tube defects, cleft lip and palate, and cardiac anomalies, as well as poor cognitive development. It should be avoided in women who are planning to conceive or are pregnant.

questions.text:
True statement regarding the administration of 5 alpha-reductase inhibitors is/are: (INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Reduces dihydrotestosterone levels

 

2. Reduces testosterone levels

 

3. Elevates PSA levels

 

4. Decreases PSA levels
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 4

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors, such as finasteride and dutasteride, are used primarily in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and conditions like male pattern baldness and hirsutism. These medications work by inhibiting the enzyme 5 alpha-reductase, which is responsible for converting testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a more potent androgen.

 

Effects of 5 Alpha-Reductase Inhibitors

 

  1. Reduces Dihydrotestosterone Levels: By inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to DHT, these drugs significantly lower DHT levels in the body. DHT is a key factor in the development and enlargement of the prostate and also contributes to hair loss.
  1. Decreases PSA Levels: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels are often reduced as a result of decreased prostate volume and reduced androgenic stimulation of the prostate. PSA is a marker used to screen for and monitor prostate cancer and other prostate-related conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

  1. Reduces Testosterone Levels: This statement is incorrect. 5 alpha-reductase inhibitors do not significantly reduce testosterone levels. In fact, due to the reduced conversion to DHT, plasma testosterone levels may remain unchanged or even increase slightly.
  2. Elevates PSA Levels: This statement is incorrect. These drugs typically decrease PSA levels due to reduced androgenic activity in the prostate.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Uses: These inhibitors are used alongside surgery and alpha-1 adrenergic blockers for treating BPH. They are also utilized in managing male pattern baldness and hirsutism.
  • Mechanism of Action: By competitively inhibiting 5 alpha-reductase, they reduce the production of DHT, which is responsible for stimulating prostate growth and hair loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors are the competitive inhibitors of the enzyme 5 alpha-reductase which converts testosterone into the more active dihydroxy testosterone (DHT). This enzyme inhibition results in:

 

 

  • Decreased DHT levels
  • Decreased PSA levels
  • Reduces prostate volume
  • However, plasma testosterone levels remain unchanged or may increase due to non-conversion to DHT.

choices.text: Spurious drug
Adulterated drug
Unethical drug
Misbranded drug

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Misbranded drug

 

A misbranded drug refers to a drug whose labeling is inaccurate or misleading. This includes incorrect labeling of the quantity of active ingredients. In this scenario, where the medication is labeled as containing 500 mg of paracetamol but actually contains only 200 mg, it would be considered a misbranded drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spurious drugs: These products are manufactured concealing the true identity of the product and made to resemble another drug, especially some popular brand, to deceive the buyer and cash on the popularity of original product. The product may or may not contain the active ingredients. Spurious drugs are usually manufactured by unlicensed anti-social elements but sometimes licensed manufacturers may also be involved.

 

Option B. Adulterated drugs: These are those drugs which are found to contain an adulterant/substituted product or contaminated with filth rendering it injurious to health

 

Option C. Unethical drug: "Unethical drug" is not a standard term in pharmaceutical regulation. The issue here is not primarily about ethics but rather about the accuracy of labeling and drug quality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A drug labeled inaccurately with respect to its active ingredient quantity is considered a misbranded drug. Ensuring accurate labeling is crucial for regulatory compliance and consumer safety, as it ensures that drugs on the market are labeled truthfully and can be trusted for their intended use.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs is associated with the increased risk of fractures? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rosiglitazone

 

Rosiglitazone, a drug belonging to the class of thiazolidinediones, has been associated with an increased risk of bone fractures. The mechanism behind this is not fully understood, but it is thought that thiazolidinediones might interfere with bone metabolism (PPARγ agonist), leading to decreased bone mineral density which can increase the risk of fractures, especially in postmenopausal women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liraglutide: It is a GLP-1 receptor agonist used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. There is no strong evidence linking liraglutide to an increased risk of fractures.

 

Option C. Voglibose: It is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor which delays the absorption of carbohydrates from the intestines. It has not been primarily associated with an increased risk of fractures.

 

Option D. Canagliflozin: It is one of the SGLT2 inhibitors that works by removing glucose through the urine. While there have been some discussions about bone density changes with SGLT2 inhibitors, canagliflozin specifically has had mixed results in studies regarding fracture risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glitazones like rosiglitazone and pioglitazone are associated with following adverse effects:

 

  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Retention of sodium and water
  • Risk of osteoporotic fractures

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors like canagliflozin is also associated with increased risk of fractures but the incidence is much lower than that with glitazones.

choices.text: Alternative RNA splicing

questions.text: Due to which phenomenon, B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alternative RNA splicing

 

B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to alternative RNA splicing.

 

Alternative splicing is the process that selectively removes introns or exons, or parts thereof, to generate multiple messenger RNAs (mRNAs) from a single precursor mRNA (pre-mRNA).

 

Humoral immunity is mediated by antibodies, which are produced by B lymphocytes.

 

Upon maturation, B lymphocytes produce IgM as the first type of immunoglobulin, followed by immunoglobulin IgG, IgE, and IgA, as a result of irreversible rearrangement of the immunoglobulin gene after activation.

 

In contrast, the IgM-to-IgD transition is produced through alternative splicing of a long primary mRNA transcript from the Ig heavy chain gene, IGH. The nuclear RNA-binding protein, HuR, is well known for its function in mRNA splicing and nuclear export.

 

Other options:

 

Options A. Somatic hypermutation and C. Affinity maturation: Affinity maturation is the process by which antibodies gain increased affinity, avidity, and anti-pathogen activity and is the result of somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, coupled to selection for antigen binding.

 

Option D. Allelic exclusion: Allelic exclusion is a process by which only one allele of a gene is expressed while the other allele is silenced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

B cells express both IgM and IgD through alternative RNA splicing, allowing the simultaneous expression of these two immunoglobulins.
